title: dog news hartpury university bacteria bowls e coli mrsa salmonella
story: Deadly bugs have been found lurking in dog drinking bowls (Image: NC)Potentially lethal E.coli, salmonella and MRSA thrive in many of the different types of pets&rsquo dishes being commonly sold across the country, putting both animal and human health at risk, say researchers.Plastic and ceramic bowls provide a more dangerous breeding ground for the potentially harmful bacteria than ones made from stainless steel.Scientists today warned for the need of &ldquosuitable cleaning regimes for the bowls which are suspected of being the third most contaminated item in any household.The threat posed by dogs&rsquo bowls has been uncovered by researchers from Hartpury University.                Robot JELLYFISH to become 's of the oceans' for coral reefs                Hurricane Florence: Pet rescuer saves DOZENS of cats and dogsAnimal Science lecturer Aisling Carroll and BSc Bioveterinary Science graduate Coralie Wright have been investigating how much the build-up of bacteria can be affected by the material a bowl is made from and how often it is cleaned.Ms Carroll said: &ldquoIt is clear from our study that dog water bowls pose a disease risk to both human and animal health.&ldquoThe increasingly close contact between humans and their pets is leading to concerns regarding bacterial transmission of zoonoses &ndash infectious diseases that be transmitted between animals and humans.&ldquoThe dog water bowl has previously been identified as the third most contaminated item within the household, which suggests that they are capable of disease transmission.Aisling Carroll with her dog Heidi at Hartpury University (Image: NC)During this latest research, the scientists looked at how popular plastic and ceramic bowls can each play different roles in harbouring notorious bacteria.Ms Carroll said: &ldquoThe aim of our study was to identify whether the material &ndash plastic, ceramic or stainless steel &ndash and length of use of a dog&rsquos water bowl influences the quantity and species of bacteria present.&ldquoOur research suggests the significant increase of bacteria found in dog water bowls with length of use demonstrates the need for suitable cleaning regimes.&ldquoWe found the highest amount of bacteria in plastic bowls over time, but the most harmful bacterial species, including E.coli and MRSA, were most frequently identified in the ceramic bowls.                Hero firefighters save family of common dolphins                 Incredible moment fox is pulled out of car grille after 12 HOURS&ldquoWhile further research is required to assess the most suitable bowl materials and cleaning practices, it is clear from our study that dog water bowls pose a disease risk to both human and animal health.Seven years ago the National Science Foundation in the United States conducted a Germiest Places in the Home study, asking families to swab 30 everyday household items to measure contamination from yeast, mould and coliform bacteria, which include salmonella and E.coli.The results highlighted the misconception that toilets were the dirtiest places.Kitchens were found to harbour the most germs, with positive swabs for coliform, an indicator of faecal contamination, turning up on 75 per cent of sponges and rags, 45 per cent of sinks and 32 per cent of counter tops.E.coli was found in the pet bowls from two homes, but less than one per cent of all other surfaces.The new investigation into drinking bowls is among a number of animal welfare related studies being conducted at Hartpury University.Hartpury University has more than 1,650 students completing undergraduate and postgraduate degrees as well as higher education diplomas and postgraduate research in sport, equine, animal, agriculture and veterinary nursing.

title: brexit news eu uk ireland eu position latest
story: Leo Varadkar said he does not expect any change in the EU's position over the impending orce after European leaders gather for an informal summit in Salzburg in Austria tomorrow.The EU's chief negotiator Michel Barnier will brief heads of government and Prime Minister Theresa May is likely to put forward her own views.The informal nature of the event means there will be no draft text or formal conclusions.The Taoiseach told Ireland's Dail parliament: I do not anticipate there will be any change to the EU's position or any change to our negotiating guidelines.                EU backs Spain in Brexit row over Gibraltar as Barnier holds talks                EU preparing EMERGENCY legislation to prepare markets for HARD-BREXITEuropean leaders have been urged by the UK to compromise on their Brexit stance on the eve of the major summit.The Prime Minister will use Wednesday's gathering in Salzburg to make a direct pitch to fellow leaders to back her isive Chequers proposals.Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab said it was time for the compromises made by the UK to be matched on the EU side.In a sign that Brexit talks could go to the wire, the European Union is preparing for a final deal to be struck at an emergency summit in November, rather than the scheduled October meeting previously targeted by both sides in the negotiations.The EU will NOT change its Brexit position (Image: getty)Dominic Raab said 'compromises' made by the UK should be 'matched on the EU side' (Image: getty)Mr Varadkar added: It is fair to say that some of the things I have been reading in the British papers, particularly the British-owned papers, are very far off the mark when it comes to the reality of what is going on at the minute with these negotiations.He said the draft withdrawal agreement between the UK and EU in December provided for various protections sought by the Irish government including transitional arrangements and the movement of people between the UK and Ireland.The Irish premier said the backstop on the Irish border represented an insurance policy which he never hoped to use.Mr Varadkar was challenged by the leader of Ireland's Labour Party, Brendan Howlin, about the Common Travel Area, which guarantees free movement of Irish and UK citizens between the two jurisdictions and said the draft Brexit Withdrawal Agreement provided for what the Irish Government needed.                Hunt says Boris could end up in &lsquoGRAVEYARD OF POLITICS&rsquo for doubtin...                Verhofstadt warned EU will 'have to compromise' over May's Brexit dealMr Howlin said the backstop did not represent the entirety of Ireland's interests.He claimed: Brexit could disenfranchise hundreds of thousands of people living in the UK.The political leader said the issue should be addressed as a matter of urgency and expressed fears Ireland could be blind-sided over Brexit.The Taoiseach said he would not provide a running commentary on negotiations.He also said Mr Barnier's suggestion that the Irish border issue be de-dramatised was about trying to move away from language like creating a border in the Irish Sea.A frontier in the Irish Sea has been strongly opposed by unionists who want to avoid any barrier between Northern Ireland and the rest of the UK.Mr Varadkar denied any constitutional move by the Irish Government to question Northern Ireland's status as a part of the UK during the Brexit negotiations.He reiterated he was equally keen to prevent a hard border between Northern Ireland and Scotland as between Northern Ireland and the Republic.

title: eu news immigration uk brexit migration watch MAC
story: The Migration Advisory Council (MAC)&rsquos 132-page report, published on Tuesday, said that a migrant&rsquos impact must be judged on &ldquoskills, employment, age and use of public services, and not fundamentally on their nationality.The recommendations which include making it easier for high skilled migrants to come to fill vital roles and harder for low skilled&nbsp labour to flood the UK market, mark a generational change in the view of migration in the UK.However, there was criticism of the report for controversial conclusions that immigrants pay more in taxes than they take in benefits and that there was no evidence the massive influx of unskilled labour has driven down wages.Lord Green of Deddington, Chairman of Migration Watch UK, said: This is a very technical report which seems blind to the impact of high levels of EU immigration on many communities in this country as a result of rapid population growth.                Angela Merkel on collision course with voters on new immigration planWith immigration adding one million to our population every three years this simply cannot go on.He also warned that the loose definition of high skilled labour in the report means &ldquothese proposals would permit continued high levels of immigration, including those with medium skills from all over the world.He added: &ldquoThe overall outcome would be to weaken immigration control rather than strengthen it.The report was drawn up after ministers asked experts to carry out an in-depth analysis on the patterns and impact of migration from the European Economic Area in July last year to help them draw up proposed new rules for after the implementation period ends in December 2020.EU nationals must face same rules to enter the UK as people from the rest of the world (Image: getty)High skilled migrants should be able to easily fill vital roles in the UK (Image: getty)The Migration Advisory Committee's (MAC) final report says that, if immigration is not part of the negotiations with the EU and the UK is deciding its future system in isolation, there should be no preference given to EU citizens.It says: A migrant's impact depends on factors such as their skills, employment, age and use of public services, and not fundamentally on their nationality.The committee emphasised that it was not expressing a view on whether immigration should be part of the negotiations.MAC chairman Professor Alan Manning said: If - and this is not an MAC recommendation - immigration is not to be part of the negotiations with the EU and the UK is deciding its future migration system in isolation, we recommend moving to a system in which all migration is managed with no preferential access to EU citizens.                BBC host forced to intervene as Farage issues BRUTAL response to SNP                BBC host SHUTS down SNP politician for being 'OUT OF STEP' with ScotsThis would mean ending free movement but that would not make the UK unusual, he said, citing Canada's approach as an example.Prof Manning added: The problem with free movement is that it leaves migration to the UK solely up to migrants and UK residents have no control over the level and mix of migration.The review also suggested the future immigration policy should favour high-skilled workers as there is clear evidence they bring benefits to the UK's public finances, innovation and productivity.But in a finding that is likely to spark opposition from some sectors, the MAC concludes that there is no need for a specific migration route for low-skilled work, with the possible exception of a seasonal agricultural scheme.The report recommends that a cap on the number of Tier 2 skilled work visas should be scrapped and the scheme opened up to migrants in medium-skilled posts.Business groups such as the CBI, who have pushed for the UK to Remain in the EU and a continuation of free movement to attract even more cheap labour, were critical of the report.Matthew Fell, UK policy director of the CBI, said: &ldquoThe current non-EU visa system is highly bureaucratic and cannot be extended to EU workers without major reform, so the MAC is right to recommend scrapping the tier 2 cap. But these proposals don&rsquot go far enough.Earlier this month, Home Secretary Sajid Javid said he would publish a white paper soon after the MAC'S findings are released.

title: vince cable jeremy corbyn labour party leader brexit referendum
story: Sir Vince said: If Jeremy Corbyn will not say 'I will support a people's vote and I will fight Brexit', Labour members should wave him goodbye.And in a swipe at Mr Corbyn, Sir Vince said: He has kept his hands clean and his image polished by hiring hard-left boot boys and girls to do his dirty work.They do the bullying and intimidation of colleagues and he claims not to know.He indulges anti-Semitic bigots and pleads ignorance.                Sturgeon accused of selling &lsquoSNAKE OIL&rsquo and hoodwinking voters                 Sturgeon told Scottish independence to be EIGHT TIMES more damaging...Sir Vince also insisted Prime Minister Theresa May does not believe in Brexit.Sir Vince said: She is dutifully delivering a policy she doesn't really believe in - failing in negotiations, losing public support - and all to appease a dwindling group of angry people in her party who will denounce her as a traitor, whatever she comes up with.Sir Vince also launched a personal attack on Boris Johnson, comparing him to US president Donald Trump, saying: Their cynical disregard for the truth, their treatment of women, and their inflammatory isive language make Boris and Donald the terrible twins of the rabid right.The Lib Dem leader called for an increase in wealth taxes as he branded Amazon, Facebook and Google world-class tax dodgers.Vince Cable has called for Jeremy Corbyn to be toppled if he doesn't back a referendum (Image: getty)Saying that the tectonic plates of British politics are shifting beneath us as Labour and the Tories become more hardline, he urged disillusioned MPs to jump ship.Much now depends on the courage of mainstream MPs in the Labour and Conservative parties. They are losing control and if they can't stop the rot, they should leave.Drawing on his own experiences of racism, Sir Vince said: I embarked on a mixed marriage in this country when racism was rife. My wife and children were being denounced as people whose very presence here would lead to rivers foaming with blood.                Labour MP TRASHES calls for new vote as Khan demands second referendum                Brexiteer MP blasts 'ELITE ESTABLISHMENT' urging May to hold new vote And I was thrown out of the parental home.Sir Vince, who has announced he wants to hand over the reins of his party to the next generation, insisted the Lib Dems need a major shake-up.Our party is still very pale and very male.Demanding a fresh EU referendum, the Lib Dem leader rounded on hardline Brexiteers by saying they got an erotic spasm from the thought of breaking with Brussels, whatever the cost to the economy.

title: Brexit news Michel Barnier Irish border EU latest Theresa May European Union
story: The European Union&rsquos chief Brexit negotiator has revealed the EU is &ldquoready to improve its Irish border proposal &ndash in an apparent climb down from Brussels' previous hardline stance on the issue.Speaking following the General Affairs Council on Article 50, the French negotiator claimed October will be the &ldquomoment of truth for Brexit negotiations adding: &ldquoWe are now on the home straight.Mr Barnier insisted that there would be no hard border in Ireland, claiming that any future deal will see a &ldquoset of technical checks and controls.He said: &ldquoOf course, we have to make headway decisively on the Irish question. The proposal for the backstop on Ireland and Northern Ireland has been on the table since February.                Barnier plots to force UK into Brexit deal that CANNOT be changed                Cable calls for Corbyn to LEAVE if Labour refuses to back referendum&ldquoIt is an insurance policy to avoid a hard-border between Ireland and Northern Ireland, whatever the future relationship may bring.&ldquoIt reflects our agreement with the UK on December 17, confirmed by Prime Minister Theresa May in her letter to President Tusk in her letter in March.&ldquoWe are ready to improve this proposal. Work on the EU&rsquos side is ongoing. We are clarifying which goods are arriving in Northern Ireland from the rest of the UK would need to be checked and where, when and by whom these checks could be performed.&ldquoWe can also clarify that most checks can take place away from the border at the company premises or in the markets.&ldquoWe need to de-dramatise the checks that are needed. These checks are caused by the UK&rsquos decision to leave the EU, its&nbspsingle&nbspmarket and the customs union.&ldquoWhat we need in the Withdrawal Agreement, is a legally operational backstop which fully respects the territorial integrity of the UK.&ldquoThis backstop will only apply until a better solution is found in&nbspthe context&nbspof our future relationship.Michel Barnier later added: &ldquoWe are working to improve our proposal. You have got to remember that the problem in Ireland, in the light of the long and positive history of the Good Friday Agreement, and the cooperation of both sides and the Common Travel Area.Brexit news: Michel Barnier claimed the EU was ready to 'improve' its offer on the Irish border (Image: )&ldquoThe problem is created here in particular for goods, by Brexit. I note Theresa May&rsquos commitment last December as she confirmed in March to find a solution.&ldquoI am attempting to display in concrete terms as I did with the Ministers and as I will to the leaders. What we are talking about here is not a land border, not a sea border, it&rsquos a set of technical checks and controls, just about all of which can not be put other than in a physical place in Northern Ireland. It will not be in any case take the form of a border.Mr Barnier also claimed that October was a &ldquomoment of truth in Brexit negotiations.He said: &ldquoThe European Council in October will be the moment of truth. It is there that we shall see whether the agreement we are hoping for is within our grasp.The Irish border issue has been a major sticking point in Brexit negotiations, with both sides insisting there will be no return of a hard-border.Mr Barnier speech comes ahead of Wednesday's informal gathering in Salzburg where Theresa May will attempt to make a direct pitch to fellow leaders to back her Chequers deal.Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab said it was time for the compromises made by the UK to be matched on the EU side.

story: Theresa May will pledge to increase social housing and end the stigmatism surrounding it (Image: )The Prime Minister will also call for an end to the stigma around social housing, as she hails a ground-breaking initiative to give the sector long-term confidence to take a lead in major projects.Housing associations, which are private and non-profit-making providers and managers of low-cost homes, will be able to bid for a share of the &pound2billion fund stretching as far ahead as 2028-29.It is the first time any government has offered associations such long-term certainty, she will tell the National Housing Federation Summit in London, which she is the first Prime Minister to address.Mrs May will say: Doing so will give you the stability you need to get tens of thousands of affordable and social homes built where they are needed most, and make it easier for you to leverage the private finance you need to build many more.                Illegal green belt sites 'rented to homeless and EU migrants'In return, she will call on associations to use their community links, expertise and ability to ride out market cycles to achieve things neither private developers nor local authorities are capable of doing.She will continue: I&rsquom asking housing associations to use the tools we have given you - not just to build more homes, though of course more homes are needed, but to take the lead in transforming the very way in which we think about and deliver housing in this country.Rather than simply acquiring a proportion of the properties commercial developers build, I want to see housing associations taking on and leading major developments themselves, because creating the kind of large-scale, high-quality developments this country needs requires a special kind of leadership - leadership you are uniquely well-placed to provide, she will tell them.She will also urge them to help change how tenants and wider society view social housing.For many people, a certain stigma still clings to social housing. Some residents feel marginalised and overlooked, and are ashamed to share the fact that their home belongs to a housing association or local authority, she is expected to say.And on the outside, many people in society, including too many politicians, continue to look down on social housing and, by extension, the people who call it their home.We should never see social housing as something that need simply be 'good enough', nor think that the people who live in it should be grateful for their safety net and expect no better.I want to see social housing that is so good people are proud to call it their home. Our friends and neighbours who live in social housing are not second-rate citizens.Mrs May's speech will be seen as part of her determination to show she has an energetic domestic policy agenda that goes beyond Brexit.                Brexit breakthrough: EU 'READY to improve' Irish border plan &ndash Barnier                Verhofstadt says EU citizens are not 'so stupid' to vote to leave EUShe has said it is a personal mission to get more people onto the housing ladder.David Orr, Chief Executive of the National Housing Federation, said: The announcement of &pound2billion of new money for social housing is extremely welcome but the really big news here is the Prime Minister's long-term commitment to funding new affordable homes. This represents a total step change.&nbsp&ldquoFor years, the way that money was allocated meant housing associations couldn&rsquot be sure of long-term funding to build much-needed affordable housing.Now, by changing the way in which they allocate funding, ministers have given long-term confidence and confirmed that we are trusted partners in solving the housing crisis, building new homes and communities.Ultimately, this will have a huge impact on building the affordable homes that thousands of people across the country desperately need.

I thought it was great that he got that last century &ndash almost a century and a half.&ldquoHe showed a very British temperament in what he was doing which was to get on with it, to put his head down and deliver.&ldquoWe should celebrate success like that and say --- good on you!

title: brexit news dominic raab brussels brexit compromise eu latest
story: Dominic Raab urged for flexibility from EU leaders to make a deal with Britain (Image: )He spoke on the eve of a meeting in Austria where Theresa Mayon Wednesday night will appeal directly to her 27 fellow EU national leaders to accept her government's blueprint as the best outcome for Europe as well as the UK.The European Commission is aiming for a final deal to be struck at an emergency summit in November, four months before Britain leaves the bloc on March 29 next year.Mr Raab, who has been spearheading talks with European Commission chief negotiator Michel Barnier, told journalists from German, French, Irish and other EU countries: We've made the compromises and we showed the ambition and we do need to see that matched on the EU side.We have shown ourselves to be very pragmatic and ambitious. The ball is little bit in the other court now.                Verhofstadt says EU citizens are not 'so stupid' to vote to leave EU                Small businesses 'unprepared' for no-deal Brexit, warns FSBThe gathering in Austria was an important milestone, a stepping stone, to show that we've actually got the contours of agreement on principles to continue the final weeks of these negotiations and hammer out the details.Mr Raab made clear the UK seeks further movement from the EU on how to keep the border between Ireland and Northern Ireland free-flowing after Brexit.Mrs May's trade plan for goods was the only one so far that guaranteed smooth commerce between Britain and the EU and took account of Ireland's particular situation, he said.Britain could not accept the EU suggestion that effectively created a customs border between Northern Ireland and mainland Britain by keeping only Ulster in the EU customs area, he stressed.He would not refuse to entertain any new proposals from the EU: But they've got to be respecting the equities that we've set out.Jeremy Hunt defended Theresa May after Boris Johnson's criticism of her Brexit plan (Image: JONATHAN BUCKMASTER)His comments were echoed by Brexit Minister Lord Callanan, who said on arrival at meetings in Brussels: If we are to get a deal there has to be compromises from both sides and we look forward to seeing what the EU side has to say about this.Unnamed EU diplomats were reported in the  as insisting it was for Britain to make substantial further compromise.One even claimed Britain needed a darkest hour moment facing a no-deal Brexit to be made to shift position - using the term coined by Winston Churchill for the early days of World War II when the British Empire and Commonwealth stood alone against Nazi Germany.But Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt today struck a more upbeat note.On an official visit to Japan he said Britain could leave the EU next March without a deal: But I don't think it's in anyone's interest for that to happen.                'The ball is in your court' Raab issues EU WARNING on eve of Salzburg                Theresa May exclusive: Brexit plan DELIVERS freedoms people voted forJeremy Hunt was the first British government minister to make a speech in Japanese (Image: )So that's why we are cautiously optimistic that we will get a deal - but there is a lot of work to do to get there.He was confident the Prime Minister would succeed with the EU, despite Tory attacks on her plan.British politics is littered with the graveyards of people who have predicted the demise of Theresa May and been proved wrong. So I think she will succeed, said Mr Hunt.Of course, Boris Johnson doesn't agree with some of the policy decisions that she's taken, but Theresa May has to speak not just for the 52 per cent who voted for Brexit, she has to speak for 100 per cent of the country and she has to find a way that builds bridges and unifies the country and that's what I'm confident she will do.Mr Hunt was the first British government minister to make a speech in Japanese, which he learned in the country as a young man in the 1990s. He was on guard to avoid a repeat of his gaffe in China earlier this year when he tried to impress his hosts with the information that his wife is Chinese, only to refer to her by mistake as Japanese.Theresa May will warn EU leaders that Brussels must offer concessions to the UK to ensure a Brexit deal.In a speech over dinner at an EU summit in Austria, the Prime Minister will insist that the UK had conceded enough in the Brexit negotiations so far and the bloc must now respond,She is expected to point out that the UK has evolved its position in the talks, so the EU must do the same to get a successful conclusion.She will say that goodwill and determination on both sides are needed on both sides to avoid a a disorderly exit and reach a deal that is in the best interests of both sides.She will also say that neither side in the talks can be expected to breach their red line commitments.Neither side can demand the unacceptable of the other, such as an external customs border between different parts of the United Kingdom.No other country would accept it if they were in the same situation, a Government source said ahead of the informal gathering of EU leaders at Salzburg.Mrs May will say the EU must respect the constitutional and economic integrity of the UK and so cannot accept any attempt to put a customs border across the Irish Sea.The official said: Similarly, the UK understands that to the EU it would be unacceptable for us to seek the rights of EU membership without the obligations. That is not what we are doing.Mrs May will say the UK is proposing a fair arrangement that works for the UK and European economies without undermining the EU's Single Market.She is add that the arrangement will be balanced by a strong security relationship to keep all our citizens safe from threats at home and abroad.

story: The Queen&rsquos animals were absent from this year's Highland Games, and the reason for this was because the Queen was afraid her herd may have contracted infectious diseases.The stockman, who is in charge of the Royal herd, said Her Majesty&rsquos cows have been kept away from the shows over health fears.He said she feels the risk of her herd coming into contact with other livestock is too great this year.The Queen founded the Balmoral fold of Highland cattle in 1953. That we will not do.&ldquoWe cannot, for example, compromise and say &lsquookay the customs union does not exist any more in the European Union and we are going to make facilitated customs arrangement with different tariffs and outsourcing or customs duties', that is not possible.&ldquoSo even when I want to compromise it is impossible to compromise on such a thing. But I think it is possible nevertheless the find a way out on this.Theresa May claimed that the alternative to her controversial Chequers agreement was a Brexit no&nbspdeal,&nbspif her blueprint was voted down in the House of Commons.The Brexit Committee published a report saying the Government&rsquos priority must be to secure a orce agreement with the European Union.The report has warned that a &lsquono deal&rsquo outcome would have big consequences for the EU and the UK and it would be &ldquochaotic and damaging for the UK economy.The Chair of the Committee, Hilary Benn MP, said: We&rsquore urging the Government to concentrate on getting a deal to ensure the continuation of tariff and friction free trade which is so important to the future of our economy.If the Chequers Plan is not acceptable as a basis for that, then the Government will need to find a different approach urgently. story: Driverless lorries could first travel between Manchester and Glasgow (Image: nc)Firms would maximise profits by deploying autonomous HGVs on the 215-mile Anglo-Scottish route because of its long distance and relatively low congestion, according to transport information firm Inrix.The second most feasible corridor would be the A1 between Sheffield and Edinburgh, followed by the M5A38 route between Plymouth and Birmingham.The M25 London orbital motorway was selected as the road where driverless lorry technology could lead to the biggest safety improvement, due to having a significantly higher levels of dangerous incidents per mile than any other route.Coventry-Manchester on the M6 was in second place. story: Jacob Rees-Mogg is arguing the Government must 'chuck Chequers' to deliver 'the right Brexit choice' (Image: )The ardent Brexiteer believes the Government is pushing back against any alternative arrangements to Chequers because it has &ldquoinvested too much pride in its own plan.The backbench MP and Tory dissident argued Chequers did not serve the best interests of the nation and it pleased &ldquonobody other than the Prime Minister herself.Writing in The Daily , he said: &ldquoThere is only one chance to make the right Brexit choice and the Government still seems miles away from it.He added: &ldquoThe answer remains to chuck Chequers and go for a free trade deal that is on offer and works with the ERG&rsquos effective answer to the Irish question.                Jacob Rees Mogg claims PM has NO support for 'Dirty Harry' Brexit plan                Brexiteers demand May scraps EU plan on eve of Salzburg summitMr Rees-Mogg referred to comments Environment Secretary Michael Gove made on Sunday in which he suggested &ldquoa future Prime Minister could always choose to alter the relationship between Britain and the European Union.The Tory rebel compared Mr Gove&rsquos assertion with the Prime Minister&rsquos &ldquofirmly stated position that Chequers is the only option other than no deal.He said: &ldquoThere is a clear inconsistency in these two views.&ldquoIf Chequers could be changed later, why not simply short-circuit the process and agree something lasting?Mr Rees-Mogg recently spoke on a report from Economists For Free Trade at houses of Parliament  (Image: )Mr Rees-Mogg is tipped as a future leader of the Conservative Party  (Image: )&ldquoBut that contradicts Theresa May&rsquos firmly stated position.&ldquoThe Prime Minister&rsquos view that it must be her deal or no deal risks sounding rather high-handed but it is also incorrect.The Brexit champion went on to point out the EU has offered a comprehensive free trade deal for the UK and would offer it for Northern Ireland as well.But Mr Rees-Mogg warned the free trade deal would only be struck if the integrity of the single market was safeguarded.                'Chequers or no deal' May warns MPs with crucial Brexit ultimatum Mrs May spoke at the United Jewish Israel Appeal (UJIA) Dinner in central London on Monday (Image: )He said: &ldquoLast week, the European Research Group, which I chair, explained how this could be done in accordance with the EU&rsquos own rules.&ldquoThese proposals were given further substance by the reports that the EU is considering compromise and technological solutions for its backstop proposal.Mr Rees-Mogg explained these conditions could extend to flows between the UK and Ireland.Ireland, the Tory MP argued, has become very important to the bloc because of the volume of Irish trade that passes through the mainland.Mr Rees-Mogg says the Chequers deal is not in the best interests of the UK (Image: )In a recent interview with the BBC&rsquos Panorama programme, Mrs May rubbished Mr Rees-Mogg&rsquos proposals to enact a &ldquoborder away from the border.Mrs May believes Mr Rees-Mogg&rsquos proposals for a remote border, where there would be checks several miles away from the physical border, will not solve the problem at all.She said: &ldquoYou don&rsquot solve the issue of no hard border by having a hard border 20 kilometres inside Northern Ireland or 20 kilometres inside Ireland - it is still a hard border.Mr Rees-Mogg has five children  (Image: )Of Mrs May&rsquos comments, Mr Rees-Mogg said: &ldquoThis is peculiar as it is already in existence.&ldquoFor excise, VAT and immigration, the border between Northern Ireland and the Republic is not currently policed at crossing points but administratively, as companies make filings or carry out checks, while customs officers act to detect crime.He added: &ldquoThis makes it clear that the opening claim is wrong.&ldquoIt is not either Chequers or the WTO there is at least one other option but the Government is stubbornly refusing to embrace it because it has invested such pride in its own plan.&ldquoUnfortunately, the suggestion of changing Chequers later is even less credible than the &ldquono alternative propaganda.

title: uk health science news latest air pollution dementia link
story: Dementia risk could be a postcode lottery depending on air pollution levels (Image: )Researchers from the University of London, Imperial College and King&rsquos College London used anonymous patient health records from the Clinical Practice Research Datalink, which collects data from GP practices.They focused on 131,000 patients aged 50 to 79 in 2004, who had not been diagnosed with dementia, registered at 75 general practices within the M25 area.The health of the patients was tracked for an average of seven years, until they were diagnosed with dementia, died or left their GP practice.Between 2005 and 2013, 2181 patients (1.7 per cent) were diagnosed with dementia, 39 per cent of whom had Alzheimer&rsquos disease and 29 per cent of whom had vascular dementia.                Dementia: Are men or women more likely to develop Alzheimer&rsquos disease?                Dementia: Is it possible to slow down symptoms?Between 2005 and 2013, 2181 patients (1.7 per cent) were diagnosed with dementia (Image:  STOCK)These diagnoses were found to be linked to ambient levels of nitrogen dioxide and the microscopic particles PM2.5, based on estimates taken near the homes of patients in 2004.Those living in areas with the top fifth of nitrogen dioxide levels had a 40 per cent higher risk of being diagnosed with dementia than those living in areas with the lowest.A similar increase was seen with levels of PM2.5 in the research findings, published in the journal BMJ Open.The links could not be explained by factors known to influence the development of the condition but were more consistent for Alzheimer&rsquos disease than vascular dementia.                Could a 53p-a-day pill help improve your memory?Further work is urgently needed to explore recent findings linking air pollution and dementia (Image:  STOCK)The diseases that cause dementia can begin in the brain up to 20 years before symptoms start to show (Image:  STOCK)The authors said: &ldquoFurther work is urgently needed to confirm and understand better recent findings linking air pollution to dementia. Our results suggest both regional and urban background pollutants may be as important as near-traffic pollutants.&ldquoThe cause of these neurodegenerative diseases is still largely unknown and may be multifactorial. While toxicants from air pollution have several plausible pathways to reach the brain, how and when they may influence neurodegeneration remains speculative.Alzheimer&rsquos Research UK described the study as a &ldquogrowing area of research, but chief scientific officer Dr David Reynolds added: &ldquoWhile the researchers tried to account for factors like wealth, heart disease and other potential explanations for differences in dementia rates across the capital, it is difficult to rule out other explanations for the findings.&ldquoThe diseases that cause dementia can begin in the brain up to 20 years before symptoms start to show.&ldquoWe don&rsquot know where people in this study lived in the two decades before their dementia diagnosis, so we have to be cautious about how we interpret these results.Separate research, presented on Sunday at the European Respiratory Society International Congress in Paris, found children who have green spaces near their homes have fewer respiratory problems such as asthma later in life.Those who are exposed to air pollution are more likely to suffer.

title: UK weather latest news storm forecast September weather 2018
story: Potentially killer gales threaten to topple trees, knock out power supplies and hurl flying debris across swathes of the country through the next 24 hours.Another violent cyclonic weather system will launch an even more vicious assault after Helene has finished her attack today, forecasters warn.The deep low-pressure system forming in the Atlantic has given rise to the first UK named storm of the season &ndash Ali &ndash on Wednesday.LATEST WEATHER FORECAST AND MAPS HEREBrutal hurricane-force winds will pummel northern, western and north-eastern Britain prompting government forecasters to issue further&nbsp &lsquodanger to life&rsquo warnings.The Met Office has issued a yellow weather warning across much of south-western, central, northern Britain and parts of eastern England ahead of Helene&rsquos arrival.Yellow and amber warnings have been issued for parts of Scotland and the north of England for Storm Ali. Falling trees, widespread travel disruption and loss of electricity supplies threaten to cripple the worst-hit regions as gales tear in from the Atlantic.                BBC Weather forecast: Shock heatwave warning as HURRICANE FORCE winds                 Storm Helene path MAPPED: When will Helene hit the UK? What time?UK weather latest: Storm Ali will hit the UK on Wednesday (Image: WX Charts)Met Office chief forecaster Steve Ramsdale said: &ldquoA spell of strong winds is expected mainly in the far southwest of England and across west and south Wales. &ldquoThe strongest winds will the transferring across the Midlands and parts of northern England during Tuesday morning and into the air and ferry transport are likely, probably some bus and train services will be affected with some journeys taking longer.&ldquoSome short term loss of power and other services is possible.The worst of the storm is expected to have passed by Tuesday evening with the next tempest on standby to barrel in shortly afterwards, forecasters say.Further Met Office warnings are in place across Scotland, northern Britain and parts of western England and Wales through Wednesday.UK weather forecast: Wednesday weather will be horrid as Storm Ali hits with 85mph winds (Image: WX Charts)Near 85mph winds whipped up by the ferocious, churning vortex threaten to tear down power cables, knock out mobile phone signals and close roads and bridges.Met Office spokesman Grahame Madge said: &ldquoAnother system on Wednesday will be more significant than Helene, wind speeds are likely to be higher.&ldquoThere will be the potential for a greater impact from the storm which will start to make itself known from Tuesday night.&ldquoIt may catch people unawares, we have been expecting Helene as an ex-hurricane for a while but this one will sneak up behind so people may be less prepared.&ldquoThis storm is the result of a low-pressure system forming in the north Atlantic, we don&rsquot know if we will be issuing a name from our own list at the moment, it is something we are keeping an open mind about.Wednesday&rsquos storm will hammer Scotland north-east England north-west England Northern Ireland Wales Yorkshire and the Humber.UK weather latest: Storm Ali forecast for Wednesday (Image: WX Charts)UK weather warning: Scotland and northern England have been issued with yellow and amber warnings (Image: Met Office)South-east England will escape the worst of the assault with a largely dry, fine albeit blustery day on the cards, forecasters say.Temperatures will remain above-average across southern England through the week thanks to warm air left in Helene&rsquos wake.Elsewhere, winds will pick up on Tuesday night before raging through Wednesday prompting warnings to expect road and bridge closures.Worrying weather charts show violent autumn storms ripping through northern Britain on Wednesday and Thursday.&nbspThe relentless blitz on Britain is due in part to a supercharged jet stream pulling storm systems across the Atlantic and into the UK, forecasters say.&nbspThe jet, a rapid current of air high in the atmosphere, is currently sweeping across the country pulling storms in like a conveyor belt.&nbspThe Environment Agency warned flooding will be a risk across northern and Western Britain through Thursday amid forecasts for heavy rain.UK weather latest: Storm Helene will hit before Storm Ali (Image: WX Charts)A spokesman said: &ldquoLocal flooding is possible from rivers and surface water in parts of the north and west of England and Wales.&ldquoLand, roads and some properties may flood and there may be travel disruption.Mr Ramsdale added: &ldquoStrong winds affecting parts of western Scotland and Northern Ireland early on Wednesday will continue to strengthen through the morning and then extend across many parts of Scotland and northern England and northwest Wales. &ldquoFor some exposed areas, in particular parts of western Scotland, gusts could reach in excess of 75 mph in places. &ldquoThe gusty winds will be accompanied in places by heavy, squally showers.&nbsp &ldquoPower cuts may occur, with the potential to affect other services, such as mobile phone coverage.UK weather latest: Storm Ali will bring vicious winds (Image: Netweather)&ldquoThere will be a danger of injuries and danger to life from flying debris.WeatherOnline forecaster Simon Keeling said severe gales will blight parts of the country through the week as the storms rattle in.He said: &ldquoA very windy spell of weather ahead during the coming week.&ldquoSevere gales are likely on many days with the risk of some minor damage to trees and buildings. The weather will be mixed too with showers or longer spells of rain. &ldquoTemperatures are going to be warm in the south and east on many days but cooler to the north.AccuWeather forecaster Eric Leister said wind and rain will be the theme for much of this week across most of Britain.He said: &ldquoThis stormy weather pattern will persist across the UK this week bringing more spells of rain and wind throughout the country.&ldquoA more potent storm will threaten the country on Wednesday and could become the first named windstorm of the season.&ldquoWednesday&rsquos windstorm will bring risks ranging from damaging winds to localised flooding, power outages and travel disruptions.&ldquoAreas from Scotland and Northern Ireland southward into Wales, Northern England and the northern Midlands will be at risk for damaging winds.Deputy Met Office meteorologist Laura Ellam said after a brief respite at the end of the week things will turn unsettled again at the weekend.She said: &ldquoThroughout this week we are expecting to see periods of strong winds across parts of the UK, as well as some heavy rain. &ldquoSome very strong winds are possible in the northern half of the UK on Wednesday, then on Thursday areas further south could see a spell of persistent rain. &ldquoThe timing and development of both these systems remains uncertain however, so please keep up to date with the warnings and forecasts. &ldquoAfter a less unsettled day on Friday, as we head through the weekend we are likely to see further Atlantic low pressure systems arriving.

title: Woolly mammoth revived extinction Siberian Jurassic Park reserve Russia
story: &ldquoIn my opinion, cloning a mammoth will happen in the next decade (Image:  )The government of Russia&rsquos Siberian Yakutia territory has given a team of scientists the go-ahead to attempt mammoth cloning.The multi-national team includes researchers from Russia, South Korea and Japan.If successful, the mega mammals will be kept in a giant Jurassic Park-style reserve.It would be the first time mammoths, which could reach 11 feet in height, have walked the Earth for 4,000 years.                Ancient mammoth remains found in Crimea cave                Stone Age KILL SITE full of mammoth remains discovered Acting head of Yakutia territory Aisen Nikolaev claimed: &ldquoIn my opinion, cloning a mammoth will happen in the next decade.&ldquoTechnology is developing at an explosive pace and what yesterday seemed to be scientific nonsense, today is an absolutely clear prospect for scientists.Mr Nikolaev was speaking at the Eastern Economic Forum (EEF) in Vlaostok.He first attracted attention when he proposed putting cloned mammoths in a Siberian ice age park in 2014.Replica mammoth in a German museum (Image:  )He told the forum: &ldquoBack in 2014 I proposed a project to create an Ice Age Park with mammoths - everybody laughed then.&ldquoBut they&rsquore not laughing now.&ldquoToday technology is developing at an explosive pace, and what yesterday seemed to e scientific nonsense today is an absolutely clear prospect for scientists.The carcass of a baby mammoth recovered in 2007 (Image: )&ldquoI believe that miracles are possible.The scientists plan to take DNA from mammoth remains found in permafrost for cloning.Woolly mammoths would likely be born and initially cared for by an elephant surrogate mother.                Scientists &ldquocloser than ever to bringing extinct Tasmanian tiger back&ldquoI believe that miracles are possible (Image: )Cloning experiments have been taking place in Yakutsk, the capital of Yakutia, on extinct ancient horses and cave lions.There is already a Pleistocene Park in Yakutia, which imitates the environment which existed when mammoth lived.It is unclear whether Mr Nikoleav hopes to use this existing facility or construct another.

title: yom kippur 2018 candle lighting prayer here yom kippur prayer
story: Yom Kippur is also known as the day of atonement and represents a time when Jews reflect on and ask for forgiveness for their sins.Jews around the world fast on Yom Kippur, abstaining from food, drink, marital relations, bathing and perfume.Lasting for 25 hours, Yom Kippur begins on the tenth day of the seventh month at sundown.The day is the holiest in the Jewish calendar, and the majority of the day is spent in synagogue services.YOM KIPPUR GREETINGS - WHAT TO SAY: HOW DO YOU SAY HAPPY YOM KIPPUR                Yom Kippur 2018: When does the Yom Kippur fast start TONIGHT?                Yom Kippur greetings: What to say to commemorate Yom KippurJews believe that God dictates each person&rsquos fate for the coming year into the Book of Life on Rosh Hashanah and waits until Yom Kippur to &lsquoseal&rsquo the outcome.Rosh Hashanah is the first day of the seventh month, whilst Yom Kippur takes place on the tenth day of the seventh month.Are candles lit on Yom Kippur?At least 18 minutes before sunset, according to Chabad.org, all women and girls light candles to welcome Yom Kippur.One candle must be large enough to burn for the full 25 hours of Yom Kippur (Image: )Should there be no women, the male head of the household will undertake the candle lighting.Candles are lit as it is impossible to honour Yom Kippur with food and drink like other holidays, as Jews are required to fast.It is not allowed for flames to be created during a holiday - instead, candles must be lit from a pre-existing flame that was burning before the holiday began.There are two candle lighting blessings and they are as follows:                Yom Kippur greetings 2018: How do you wish someone a Happy Yom Kippur?                Yom Kippur 2018: When does the Yom Kippur fast start TONIGHT?The first -Bo-ruch a-toh Ado-noi E-lo-hei-nu me-lech ho-olom a-sher ki-de-sha-nu be-mitz-vo-sov ve-tzi-vo-nu le-had-lik ner shel Yom Ha-kipurim.Translation: Blessed are you, Lord our God, King of the universe, who has sanctified us with His commandments, and has commanded us to kindle the light of the Day of Atonement.The second -Ba-ruch A-tah Ado-nai E-lo-hei-nu Me-lech ha-o-lam she-he-che-ya-nu ve-ki-yi-ma-nu ve-hi-gi-ya-nu liz-man ha-zeh.Translation: Blessed are You, Lord our God, King of the universe, who has granted us life, sustained us, and enabled us to reach this occasion.Many candles are lit to honour the day as Jews fast so can not honour it with food (Image: )Yom Kippur is a time for reflection and prayer (Image: )Isaiah wrote, &ldquoWith lights, honour God which is why often many candles are lit in homes and synagogues.However, only married men light candles in the synagogue wherein past times both young and old would have candles lit for them.One candle in the synagogue should be large enough to burn for the entire 25 hours of Yom Kippur.This candle is known as &ldquodos lebidikeh licht in Yiddish, which translates to &ldquothe living light.Another name for this candle is &ldquodos gezunteh licht which means &ldquothe healthy light.

title: chequers deal brexit theresa may cabinet
story: The Prime Minister, however, faces substantial opposition from within the Conservative Party to the plan. Heres what you need to know.After a marathon session of talks at Chequers on July 6, Theresa May managed to secure a Brexit plan which will be assessed by the EU.Her Brexit plan will see the UK remains closely tied to the Brussels.It also includes the creation of a new UK-EU free trade area for goods, with a common rulebook.This rulebook could limit the UKs ability to strike trade deals with countries such as the US, for whom securing market access for American farmers would be a big prize.Mrs May has agreed to an amendment that would stop Britain being tied to Europes customs union after we quit the EU.In dramatic scenes in the House of Commons on July 17 2018, Mrs May managed to see off a damaging attempt, winning by just six votes.Mrs May was then defeated on a separate amendment to her flagship Trade Bill, which will require her to seek continued UK participation in the EUs system for regulation of medicines after Brexit.Now her Cabinet is required to ensure that the UK can continue to participate in the regulatory network operated by the European Medicines Agency.Mrs May hopes to get an agreement hammered out at a series of summits with EU leaders this autumn, and bring it back to Parliament for approval.A deal on the UKs withdrawal agreement was expected to be agreed in time for the summit in October, along with a statement from both sides on the future relationship.However, a number of senior figures have said this deadline may slide into November.Once a dead has been agreed, MPs will be asked to approve it.In a Panorama interview in September 2018 she said MPs had a simple choice between her Chequers plan or no deal.She told the BBC current affairs programme: I think that the alternative to that [the Chequers plan] will be not having a deal.The former Foreign Secretary claimed Mrs Mays disastrous plans for the Irish border would leave Britain at a loss.Boris Johnson said the European Unions fallback position for the Irish border would mean Northern Ireland was annexed by Brussels.Opposition to the plan in the Conservative Party centres around the European Research Group of hard - Brexit supporting MPs led by Jacob Rees - Mogg.His voice had been among the loudest voicing their objection to the plan and he urged MPs “chuck Chequers”.Up to 80 Tory MPs are prepared to vote against Theresa Mays Chequers plan, Steve Baker, a former Brexit minister and ERG backer has warned.A group of about 50 Tory MPs have met to discuss how and when they could force her out of her job, the BBC reported.Also voicing his opposition to the Chequers deal has been former Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson.He said Theresas Mays had wrapped a suicide vest around the British constitution and handed the detonator to Brussels.Along with former Brexit secretary David Davis and Mr Johnson resigned in protest following the Chequers meeting.Several other MPs also quit their ministerial posts over the issue, including Steve Baker, Maria Caulfield, Ben Bradley and Robert Courts.The party will vote down any Brexit deal brought back from Brussels by Theresa May, according to shadow Foreign Secretary Emily Thornberry.The Corbyn ally said the party will oppose it to try to force an election by Christmas.Speaking to the FT she said a deal which meets her party’s tests was “not going to happen”, and therefore the Prime Minister would be forced to quit.Without the support of the opposition party, it would need just a handful of Tory rebels to vote against her to see it defeated.Theresa Mays initial plans brought her on side with those Conservatives who favour a soft Brexit.The Prime Minister has also been seeking grassroots Tory support for the plan.Among those voicing support for the Prime Minister has been Environment Secretary Michael Gove, who was a prominent member of the Leave campaign.He said he was confident that the Prime Minister will go into the Conservative Party conference and beyond, securing a good Brexit deal for Britain and continuing to ensure the country enjoys good economic growth and we take advantage of Brexit.A plan may have been cooked up but it still needs to get past the EU — and the continent’s leaders are showing no sign of compromise.Angela Merkel is already rubbishing our proposal.The Napoleonic Emmanuel Macron thinks he’s a political messiah, and he’d rather see us punished than give up on his federalist promised land.And Michel Barnier’s dangled “concessions” amount to a demand for total UK capitulation.With that level of zeal and stubbornness, it’s no wonder we voted in our millions to leave.We must now go to Brussels with an offer that guarantees control of our borders and sign our own trade deals.But we mustn’t for a second think that they’ll just say yes to it, nor can the PM let them fatally weaken it.It is galling that ministers have spent more time fighting between themselves than preparing for a “no deal” exit.But it isn’t too late.New technology can ensure that Whitehall and our borders are ready for a clean break, which considering the strength of our economy and our companies is nothing to be scared of.The PM has dumped many of her earlier Brexit slogans. But she should remember one in particular now.No deal really is better than a bad deal, and we must still prepare for it.

title: biggest hurricanes history wilma katrina florence
story: The same weather system is called a cyclone in the Indian Ocean and a typhoon in the western Pacic Ocean.The Great Hurricane of 1780 is regarded as being the deadliest on record and resulted in the death of 20,000 people.The hurricane occurred before the advent of modern storm tracking technology so many details are unclear, such as its exact strength and where it originated.It is, however, believed to have first made landfall on October 10 in Barbados, where it killed 4,500 people, before sweeping over much of the rest of the Caribbean.The hurricane stripped the bark off trees and left none standing on the island and meteorologists have estimated the damage was caused by winds in excess of 200 mph.There were also reports of heavy cannons being thrown 100 feet into the air.As well as Barbados, Martinique and St. Lucia were hardest hit, and there were thousands of casualties on these islands, along with signicant damage to property.The deadliest hurricane to hit the United States was in 1900 when 12,000 people died in the city of Galveston, Texas, about a third of its population.In recent times, Hurricane Katrine struck the US in August 2005 and caused over £100billion worth of damage and killed at least 1,200 people.In September 2018, Hurricane Florence left at least 17 people dead after making landfall on the east coast of the US, devastating North Carolina, bringing with it biblical floodingAuthorities ordered the immediate evacuation of up to 7,500 people living within a mile of a stretch of the Cape Fear River and the Little River, about 100 miles from the North Carolina coast.The evacuation zone included part of the city of Fayetteville which has a population of 200,000.Reliable records of hurricanes began being kept in 1851 and since then there have been 905 storms of at least hurricane intensity.The intensity of a hurricane is determined either by its winds speed or its lowest barometric pressure.Hurricane Patricia is the most powerful hurricane ever recorded in the western hemisphere, hitting the Pacic coast of Mexico with winds of 202mph.Hurricane Allen holds the for the highest wind speed recorded in the Gulf of Mexico with 190mph.When it comes to intensity, Hurricane Wilma in 2005 holds the record for the lowest barometric pressure.The Saffir-Simpson scale has five categories of hurricane ranging from Category 1 with speeds of 74-95mp to Category 5 with speeds of 157 mph or above.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: inside the tiny island of mirrors where 100 pairs of twins live one in every three families and no one knows why
story: Thats because Alabat, home to just 15,000 people, is home to more than 100 pairs of twins.Right now, 78 are non-identical and 22, including four-month-olds Gian and John, look exactly the same.Those two lads are the youngest while Eudosia and Antonia, 86, are the oldest, MailOnline reports.And just to trick people into thinking there might actually be a glitch in the Matrix, many dress the same.Antonia, who married when she was 19, said her husband had a clever way of telling them apart.She said: In the initial days my husband would often mistake Eudosia for me.There were some embarrassing moments when my husband made amorous overtures to my sister thinking that it was me.I then showed him that I have a mole on my nose while my sister does not have one. That solved the problem.The number of twins on Alabat may even have gone up in the last few years.In 2013, Transterra Media reported around 60 of them on the island.At the time, the mayor said four per cent of the islands 12,039 residents were twins.He and his we were shocked to find so many on the island when they migrated there in the 1980s.A historic study found a 182 per cent increase in multiple pregnancies in 35-year-old women between 1996 to 2006 due to the use of fertility drugs.But this could not have influenced Alabat, a remote island which did not have access to the medication.No scientic studies have been carried out to find out why there is such a high ratio of twins on the island.

title: karren brady column alcohol vanity good health
story: One day, butter is the enemy. The next it’s sugar. Then carbs. A few weeks later, sugar is back on the naughty step.It’s the same with alcohol. Until recently, a glass of wine a day kept heart attacks at bay. Last month, we learned that NO amount of alcohol is safe. Then this week our new goal, apparently, should be two teetotal days a week.It’s hard to keep up — and no wonder many people ignore all the reports. Who wants to be told what to do by a bunch of scientists who can’t make up their mind?But the latest news from Public Health England should give us all pause for thought, because British women now have some of the lowest le expectancies in Europe.Girls born in the UK today can expect to die three-and-a-half years earlier than girls in Spain, the country that comes out top in this report. The reasons? Rising levels of obesity and poor cancer survival rates.British women also fare badly when it comes to premature deaths — defined as before 75.Many are caused by cancer, heart disease, stroke and type 2 diabetes, which are linked to smoking, alcohol and junk food.France, home of Michelin star chefs, is also way down on the list. And so is Italy.My supporting evidence is that I live with an Italian, who would be more likely to attend a funeral in a jester’s hat than eat a bag of crisps.Clearly, we all need to take a leaf out of the same book.The prevailing wisdom is that it’s more expensive to eat healthily. But that’s not true.A recent report from the Institute of Economic Affairs shows it’s possible to have your five-a-day for less than 30p — and a nutritious,  plain, diet can be bought for less than £1 a day.Meanwhile, the cheapest adult meal in McDonald’s is about £4.50, for which you could make a fresh vegetable curry for the whole family.So it’s not about money. Why, then, do us British women fare so badly?I wonder  we are so daunted by images of women airbrushed to perfection, in adverts and on social media, we feel we can’t compete. So we give up, eating what we like and not exercising.Because keeping really fit takes serious work.The latest insight into this is from movie star Mark Wahlberg who shared his daily schedule this week.He’s in bed by 7.30pm then up at 2.30am for the first of his two daily workouts. His fitness schedule only allows for two hours’ “work” a day — and thus it becomes clear his job is, in fact, his physique.Since most of us spend at least ten hours a day working and commuting, you can see why it’s often easier not to bother.But it’s not just our health that’s in peril. It’s also that of our children, for whom we are the primary role models.Not about vanity, but good healthI have evidence in the form of my best friend, who is a marathon-running exercise junkie — as is her daughter.I, on the other hand, although not proud of this fact, do no exercise — and my daughter doesn’t enjoy it as much as her friends.Getting fit and losing weight can feel impossible.But look at Labour deputy leader Tom Watson, who this week announced that he has lost 7st and put his Type 2 diabetes in remission, which is pretty inspiring.So let’s choose to make this bad news story into a positive and use it as inspiration for change.Let’s aim for two booze-free days a week.And maybe ditch the biscuits for a bit and make some other small, sustainable changes that will leave us able to go for a brisk walk without fearing a heart attack.This is not about vanity, it’s about good health. Because the alternative is sobering.When it started off 18 years ago it was innovative and exciting TV. But now it’s degenerated into a hotbed of fame-hungry wannabes pitted against each other and behaving horribly as a result.Now it’s been axed. About time, too.I BELIEVE in people’s right to protest – of course – against political views they disagree with. But, Ian Bone, the protestor who assailed Jacob Rees-Mogg and his children on their own doorstep has crossed a line.“Your daddy is a horrible man,” Mr Bone told Mr Rees-Mogg’s bewildered-looking children, who will likely be traumatised by the incident – and will certainly not forget.MPs are already putting a lot on the line to serve their country. Many endure threats of violence or even death – and just look at what happened to Jo Cox.Yes, it’s fine to disagree with politicians and to protest. But taking it out on children and trying to make them feel bad about their father is bullying behaviour that is wholly unacceptable.Speaking to LBC afterwards, Mr Bone, who is 71, said that he saw no problem with involving children in his protest.But despite being happy to bring Mr Rees-Mogg’s offspring into the argument, he refused to speak about his own five children, and repeatedly refused to answer  he would have been happy for them to be treated in the same way.Talk about hypocritical.EVERYONE praised as progress the BBC’s “solution” to the inequality on comedy panel shows, which has been to ensure there is at least one woman on every show.But then we hear from Sandi Toksvig that their contributions are often edited out.The QI host told the Radio Times: “There are panel shows that struggle to get women on, and that’s because . . . in the edit they are often seen just laughing at the boys and not saying anything at all, even though I know for a fact in the recording they were clever.”Turns out that turning up and being funny isn’t quite enough,  you are a woman, to be given the same air time as men. How annoying.MY Woman of the Week award goes to Carol Vorderman who, at 57, is clearly in her absolute element and loving le.She looks healthy and oozes confidence, especially in these skin-tight jeans.She told ITV’s Lorraine this week she’s happy being single and is not looking for a “keeper” or another intense relationship.In fact, she said she “couldn’t think of anything worse”.How refreshing. And what a great role model she is for women in their fties and beyond.WATCHING the video of a homeless man being sprayed with paint in Middlesbrough made my blood boil.The poor man – who was found dead just days later in a cemetery – is filmed sat against a wall, covered in paint, as a man brags: “This is how we dealwith the beggars on the street.”This disregard for another human being’s dignity is obscene and the yob should be made to volunteer helping homeless people.Until he sees that dehumanising this man who had hit troubled times was the lowest of the low.DID you see Madonna’s daughter, 21-year old Lourdes hitting the runway for the Gypsy Sport Spring Summer 2019 showcase at New York Fashion Week?It’s so dispiriting, isn’t it, that the headline news about her appearance, which could have focused on so many dferent things – her incredible confidence, for one – was that . . . she hadn’t shaved her legs, top.I guess true equality will have been achieved when a woman’s hairy calves go unmentioned and are seen as neither here nor there.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: tony blair nick clegg and john major meet with european leaders in secret plot to keep britain in the eu
story: The two former Prime Ministers and former Deputy Prime Minister have meet with senior politicians in Europe in bid to persuade them to stop the UK leaving the European Union.They have also been working with other prominent Remainers including Peter Mandelson.The mission was begun by Mr Clegg independently but he has taken on the role of informal co-ordinator of the group,  reported.In recent weeks Clegg he met Mark Rutte, the Dutch prime minister and the foreign policy team of the French president, Emmanuel Macron.He has also met senior German politicians including Bundestag president Wolfgang Schäuble and Peter Altmeier, the German economics minister.Last week Blair met senior politicians in Germany and Austria and Italy’s new interior minister, Matteo Salvini as well as the EU’s chief Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier.Both have said they would be looking for Article 50 to be extended so a deal can be struck to remain in the EU that addresses concerns about immigration.“The aim of the visits is to persuade EU leaders that British politics has made the option of remaining inside the EU viable,” said Mr Clegg.“It is a question of pressing them to keep open the extension of the article 50 process beyond the March deadline to give UK negotiators more time including to prepare legislation on a people’s vote.“We cannot just turn the clock back to just before the 2016 referendum.“There would have to be some changes of freedom of movement - we cannot just put Humpty Dumpty back together again.”Mr Blair, who met Barnier on 18 July, said the main focus of his meetings was discuss a new common approach to immigration in the UK and EU.“You cannot deal with this Brexit issue unless you deal with the questions of immigration and the anxieties that gave rise to it,” he said.At a meeting on Wednesday night in Salzburg, Austria, Theresa May will have a chance to try to persuade other EU leaders to adopt her Chequers plan to for the future relationship with Brussels.

title: jacob rees mogg column theresa may brexit
story: The Prime Minister will head to the continent on Thursday to visit Salzburg — like Bath, a world heritage city — to discuss her Brexit or Chequers proposals with other leaders of European governments.To date the EU has been officially dismissive of the main elements of Chequers, the complex customs arrangements and continued use of European Rules to secure access to the single market.Michel Barnier, who led the negotiations for the EU, has been clear that the EU cannot accept this position.The UK must either be in the Single Market with all that goes with it — including free movement — or it may have a free trade deal instead.In a sense, he is the keeper of the Orlamme for the EU.Historically, this was a sacred banner carried into battle for the kings of France when no prisoners were to be taken.The heads of government may be more conciliatory and keener to help a fellow leader, not least as most of them face their own domestic dficulties.It is also the usual form for the EU to make a deal.It protests that it is strictly a rules-based organisation to maximise its negotiating strength but then, like an honest costermonger, makes the necessary trade.At the same time the British Government seems desperate to agree something on almost any terms.Chequers rubbed out the Prime Minister’s red lines to leave the UK “half in, half out” subject to EU regulations in crucial areas of the economy, and to the European Court of Justice.The vassal has been put in chains.This desperation means it will be important to watch carefully what comes out of Salzburg.Any deal will be hailed initially as a triumph because of the hostile comments made not only by Mr Barnier but, in his recent state of the Union speech, by Jean-Claude Juncker.Overcoming these obstacles will be portrayed as a triumph for British diplomacy.Those who hope that Brexit will continue to mean Brexit will need to stay awake.The first item to watch out for is money. There is no legal obligation to pay anything at all.This has been established by the House of Lords and no credible authority has questioned their Lordships.If we pay £40billon we must get something clear in , not just wishy-washy promises.Taxpayers would be outraged  it were otherwise.Any agreement on immigration must be examined with great care.We will doubtless be told that free movement has ended but, as Shakespeare wrote, “what’s in a name? that which we call a rose by any other name would smell as sweet”.There ought to be no preferential terms for new arrivals from the EU above those offered to other nations and no access to state benefits.There must be a clear dferentiation in their rights after we have left and admission must be subject to a work permit scheme focused on skilled rather than unskilled labour.The solution to the Irish question is a further area where Brexiteers must be alert. Last week the European Research Group, which I chair, produced a paper explaining how it could be answered on the EU’s terms.Obviously the UK could simply say that there will be no physical infrastructure at the border but  instead we examine what the EU does on its other borders, and see  those precedents could be followed, then no reasonable person would think a “hard” border were necessary.So far the inevitable attacks on our reports have been mere rudery. No one has found fault with facts.If Ireland were used to justy the major concessions the Government is giving then we would know the deal is a bad one based on a false premise.It would be better than any other which the EU has so far agreed but Ireland is supposed to make it impossible.The issue has been used by those who are fearful of leaving the EU to keep us bound by its rules and regulations.Inevitably these complex machinations have led to some gossip about the leadership.These stories come from all wings of the Party with pro-Europeans such as Tom Tugendhat and George Freeman suggesting it is time to move to a new generationHowever, it is worth remembering the Prime Minister’s virtues.She is determined, thorough and dutul, and in my view duty is an heroic virtue.This gives her great strength and without a clear Parliamentary majority it is not obvious that anyone else could steer the negations to a conclusion.Pitt the Younger was hailed as the pilot who weathered the storm. Changing the pilot would not affect the weather.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brussels chequers corbyn number 10
story: Her task is to sell her botched Chequers deal on Brexit to 27 EU leaders who think it is rubbish.Her half-in, half-out formula has been trashed by Tories, Labour and even by Brussels.Nobody likes it. Nobody wants it.But this self-described “bloody dficult woman” believes she alone can ram it through.Either she knows something nobody else does . . . or her fabled “polished turd” is about to hit the fan.On tonight’s BBC’s Panorama, Mrs May spells out the formula she thinks propelled her to the top: “You bide your time and you are bloody dficult when it really matters.”Others fear a dferent characteristic has defined her political career, especially as Home Secretary.“She is mulishly stubborn,” says a former ally.“Once she digs her heels in, nothing can sht her — right or wrong.”They fear she will stick defiantly to her half-baked plan until she runs out of road and is forced to choose between an EU fudge or defeat in the House of Commons.The Chequers deal is flawed by the fantasy we can follow an EU rule book on free trade and regulation while reserving the right to duck and e.Outside Cabinet, Tories on all sides — Brexiteers and Remainers — insist it is unworkable.“It fails to take back control of our laws, borders, money and trade,” writes ex-Tory leader Iain Duncan Smith.“We would be out of Europe yet still run by Europe.”EU negotiator Michel Barnier fears it endangers the whole EU project, which is already threatened by tensions over mass immigration, the Euro and jobless school leavers.Special treatment for the UK would instantly trigger demands from other member states for their own tailor-made deals, unravelling the drive for ever-closer union.Mrs May claims there is no alternative to Chequers.But there has to be — and Britain is already working on it.Despite Chancellor Phil Hammond’s blundering interference, preparations for a clean break are in train, covering everything from free trade to the vexed border with Northern Ireland.It may be pitched as a last-ditch option, only to be deployed in an emergency.But since Chequers is universally seen as a non-starter, free trade automatically becomes the only viable plan on the UK table.New Brexit minister, karate black belt and rising star Dominic Raab, is making this vividly clear in Brussels.He alarmed Downing Street by threatening to withhold the EU’s £40billion ransom  they push us too far.And he has told Barnier to do his own dirty work and impose a border in the Irish Sea  he dares.This is music to the ears of Tory MPs who desperately yearn to see some fighting spirit.They hope against hope Mrs May secretly has a cunning plan, ready to roll out at the right moment as she suggests, calling Barnier’s bluff.But there is another red card on the table, face up and flashing danger to our EU neighbours.Do they want to humiliate the PM to the point where she is defeated in Parliament and pushed into a second catastrophic election?EU leaders can read the polls which put Labour in front.They will also be horried to see ex-Tory vice-chairman Jeffrey Archer unhelpfully saying he would vote for Corbyn  he were a Northerner.And we should all be alarmed by David Cameron’s Goldman Sachs-trained Treasury minister, Jim O’Neill, saying: “I find myself struggling to be that scared by the prospect of a Corbyn government.”The EC has enough on its plate with the growing explosion of anti-Brussels populism across Europe. The last thing it wants any time soon is a hard-left Labour government led by lelong EU-haters Jeremy Corbyn and Marxist Chancellor John McDonnell.It might be the one bargaining chip that makes Michel Barnier blink first.For a Bank of England governor, his forecast of a 35 per cent crash in house prices verged on the hysterical.Project Fear has lost the power to shock, but it won’t stop trying.Aircraft will not fall from the sky, the Channel Tunnel will stay open, NHS patients will not starve or die from lack of NHS drugs.Not only have Carney’s nightmare scenarios of slump and mass unemployment proved false, the reverse has happened.Young workers are flocking to the UK for jobs. Wages are rising. Growth is strong.Now we see French companies such as Chanel stampeding to invest billions here. Unilever, one of the biggest firms on the planet, is reviewing rash plans to move to Holland . . .All despite Brexit.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes.
