title: 5 brexit immigration myths experts
story: News5 Brexit immigration myths that experts just busted - and it's awkward for Nigel FarageIt's no secret that immigration - and fears about it - fuelled Brexit. Two years later, the Migration Advisory Committee has picked those fears apartShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor16:41, 18 SEP 2018Updated18:14, 18 SEP 2018NewsNigel Farage was a key campaigner against immigration. How to his claims stand up to scrutiny?"Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIt's no secret that immigration - and fears about it - fuelled the vote for Brexit. But today an expert report makes extremely awkward reading for some of Leave's biggest champions, including ex-UKIP leader Nigel Farage. The Migration Advisory Committee concluded there should NOT be preferential treatment for EU migrants after 2020 compared to those from the rest of the world. And it said low-skilled workers should be limited, while higher-skilled ones should be encouraged. But while this may look like a Brexiteers' boon, it's not all one sided at all. The report also picked apart a string of the most pervasive myths behind the Leave vote. We've highlighted some of the more illuminating passages - and compared them to quotes they directly contradict by one Mr Nigel Farage. If only we had this in 2016, eh?  What Nigel Farage said: We must be completely mad, as a country, to be giving people from Eastern Europe in-work benefits... Even  I thought, which I don't, there was an economic benefit to mass immigration some things are more important than money, namely the shape of our society and giving our own youngsters a chance to work.  What today's report says: The average adult migrant from the European Economic Area  contributed approximately &pound2,300 more to the UK public finances than the average adult resident in the UK. The average non-EEA migrant contributed around &pound840 less than the average adult resident in the UK. Far from being a drain on resources the MAC found that European migrants - especially those from EU13 which makes up older members of the bloc - pay more in taxes than they receive in benefits and use in public services. It's only non-EU migrants, who are already subject to visa controls, who on average contribute less than native Brits.   What Nigel Farage said:  The problem we’ve got is a population crisis caused by government policy on immigration. The problem is we haven’t got enough hospitals, we haven’t got enough doctors, we haven’t got enough facilities... Right now it’s pretty much at breaking point.  What today's report says: EEA migrants contribute much more to the health service and the provision of social care in financial resources and through work than they consume in services. EEA workers are an increasing share of the health and social care workforces though these sectors employ greater numbers of non-EEA migrants. There is no evidence that migration has reduced the quality of healthcare. 3. Migrants have had little impact on jobs for British citizens...   What Nigel Farage said: I would rather we had communities that were rather more united and we had a situation where young unemployed British people had a realistic chance of getting a job.  What today's report says:  In this report we assessed the impact of migration on the labour market, including on employment and wages. Taking all the new evidence into account we found that migrants have no or little impact on the overall employment and unemployment outcomes of the UK-born workforce. The impact may y across dferent UK-born groups with more negative effects for the lower-skilled and more positive effects for the higher-skilled. However, our robustness checks suggest that these findings are subject to uncertainty.   What Nigel Farage said: There is no question that [immigration] has pushed wage inflation down it’s helped big companies and big corporations and big landowners to make bigger profits - no argument about that.  What today's report says: In terms of wages the existing evidence and the analysis we present in the report suggests that migration is not a major determinate of the wages of UK-born workers. We found some evidence suggesting that lower-skilled workers face a negative impact while higher-skilled workers benefit, however the magnitude of the impacts are generally small. 5. Migrants are not the *biggest* reason Brits struggle to get a council house

title: no deal brexit make harder
story: NewsNo Deal Brexit will make it harder for police to protect UK citizens warns top officerSara Thornton said they will be forced to fall back on "slower, more bureaucratic" systems, making the country more vulnerableShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByTom Pettor20:42, 18 SEP 2018NewsTheresa May is still using No Deal as a fallback option "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA no-deal Brexit will make it harder for police to protect British citizens, a senior officer has warned. Sara Thornton said they will be forced to fall back on slower, more bureaucratic systems, making the country more vulnerable to the dangers of terrorism, organised crime and foreign offenders. If the country crashes out of the EU in March, police operations like the major investigation into the Novichok poisoning will be affected. Mr Thornton, chairwoman of the National Police Chiefs' Council, said: The fallbacks we're going to have to use will be slower, will be more bureaucratic and it will make it harder for us to protect UK citizens and make it harder to protect EU citizens. We are determined to do everything we can to mitigate that, but it will be hard. She said it will take ten times longer for British police to check  a foreign suspect had convictions in their home country, up from six to 66 days. European Arrest Warrants have been issued for the two Russian GRU agents suspected of the Salisbury poisoning, meaning that  they enter Europe they should be arrested.  But UK law enforcement would lose access to the power  no deal is secured, and police would be forced to negotiate inidually with each country. Ms Thornton went on: A very current example would be the two GRU officers who were responsible for the Novichok attack. If they are to step out of Russia into Europe there are European Arrest Warrants waiting for them. If we lose the European Arrest Warrant on March 29 because there was no deal, no agreement, then we have to rely on the 1957 convention and it's longer, more complicated extradition process and they don't always apply in all countries. Ms Thornton spoke as plans were unveiled for a new unit that will oversee how forces use alternative systems in the event of a no-deal Brexit. There are 40 tools that UK law enforcement may lose access to, including the EAW and the Schengen Information System, an intelligence database that was accessed 539 million times by British authorities last year alone.

title: vince cable conference speech 5
story: NewsVince Cable conference speech: 5 key moments as Lib Dem leader savages Brexit and Amazon - and blurts out an 'exotic spresm'From Amazon to erotic spasms - or not - here are the five most important things we learned from Vince Cable’s speech to Lib Dem conference 2018Share&nbsp&nbspCommentsByBen GlazeDeputy political editorMikey SmithPolitical reporterDan Bloom15:13, 18 SEP 2018Updated15:32, 18 SEP 2018Newsthis.style.display='none'"/Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror/news/video/vince-cable-fluffs-lines-during-13266736,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-M3TH25P,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:,],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true""Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailSir Vince Cable took aim at Jeremy Corbyn, tax-avoiding corporations and hardline Brexiteers today in his keynote speech to Lib Dem conference. Speaking at the climax of the four-day event in Brighton, he said Brexit would be Brexiteers' ‘erotic spasm’. At least he tried to. But when the big moment arrived he failed to deliver - and called it an exotic spresm. You might say it was an anticlimax. Or he c**ked it up. Or when it came to the big moment he couldn't perform. You get the picture. So apart from that obvious and fantastic highlight, what did the Lib Dem leader actually say? Here are the five most important things we learned from Vince Cable’s speech to Lib Dem conference 2018.  Announcing a crackdown on greedy housebuilders, tax dodgers and Amazon, it's clear who the Lib Dem leader sees as his competition. Just a year after calling for more grown-up politics, Vince Cable launched a vicious attack on Jeremy Corbyn , saying he should wave goodbye  he does not back a second referendum on Brexit . He used to be the campaigning backbencher who joined us in opposing the Iraq War and defending civil liberties, he said. In his new role he has kept his hands clean and his image polished by hiring hard left bootboys and girls to do his dirty work. They do the bullying and the intimidation of colleagues and he claims not to know. He indulges anti-Semitic bigots and pleads ignorance.  Sir Vince accused Mr Corbyn's inner circle of until recently being on the Stalinist wing of the microscopic British Communist Party with policies more relevant to the steam age than to the digital age. Quoting a Tory attack line, he declared: We do not believe in magic money trees and pots of gold at the end of the rainbow. And comparing both Labour and Tories to a cult, he added: The tectonic plates of British politics are shting beneath us. The two big parties have changed from broad churches into intolerant cults. And those who question the faith are unwelcome. The Labour leadership is dominated by people who believe in doctrines far removed from the sensible social democratic tradition which prevailed from the days of Clement Atlee to Gordon Brown. They in turn are the mirror image of the Tory zealots who have more in common with UKIP than their party’s one-nation traditions. People of moderate, decent, humane views are being marginalised as this new Illiberal International takes shape. 2. He declared war on Amazon  Vince Cable demanded a fresh war against “world class tax-dodgers” like Amazon, Facebook and Google in a bid to revive high streets. The Lib Dem leader vowed to spearhead “a renewed offensive” on corporate tax avoidance, which he warned was ruining traditional shops and stores. He also called for HM Revenue and Customs to publish tax reports of firms operating in Britain as a way of persuading companies to cough up. Addressing activists at Lib Dems' Brighton conference, Sir Vince said: “Every citizen and company should pay their fair share and get something for what they put in. “Nothing gets up the noses of honest taxpayers more than a government squeezing every penny it can out of small firms while rolling out the red carpet for world-class tax-dodgers like Amazon, Facebook and Google. “To that end we want a renewed offensive against inidual and corporate tax-dodging.  “In addition, we will scrap outdated business rates, which are destroying our high streets, and reform company taxation for the digital age.” Web firms have been accused of shting money around the world to minimise taxes. They insist they pay all cash due in every country. Today's speech also declared war on housebuilders. The Lib Dem leader said: Big housing developers like Barratts, Berkeley Homes, and Persimmon are mainly land speculation machines with a side line in house building. Elsewhere he repeated plans to scrap inheritance tax and replace it with a levy on large financial gts received over someone's letime. Under separate plans the Lib Dems would also tax capital gains from assets at the same rate as income from employment - up to 45% - and raise taxes overall. Lastly pension tax relief would be rebalanced away from the highest earners towards those least able to save. 3. He warned of riots after Brexit  In a move that surprises literally no one, Sir Vince is making a big push for a second referendum on Brexit. It really beggars belief that the army and the police are now being asked to prepare for riots in the chaotic aftermath of a botched Brexit, he said. And billions – billions – of taxpayers’ money spent preparing for disaster. He claimed the Lib Dems have gained 10,000 members in 10 days as the party campaigns against a costly and painful exit. In a quote that risks accusations he is insulting voters' intelligence, he said: Brexit still appeals to many hearts,  not to many minds. And he said people had suffered a move from skilled and respected jobs to crap jobs - from certainty to insecurity. 4. He revealed his family chucked him out for having a mixed-race marriage  The 75-year-old spoke movingly about his own experience of racism, during his marriage to first we, Olympia, a nurse originally from Goa. The Lib Dem leader told the hall his parents threw him out of their home over the marriage. “I embarked on a mixed marriage in this country when racism was re,” he said. He told the hall his we and three children were “being denounced as people whose very presence here would lead to rivers foaming with blood. “And I was thrown out of the parental home. “So I will never waver in my commitment to call out and stand up to racism in all its forms.” “But,” he added. “We must understand that to dismiss all Brexit voters as racists is simply wrong and utterly counterproductive.” Sir Vince also refused to accept the idea that wanting immigration to be managed “like other parts of the economy” was racist. 5. He compared Boris Johnson to Donald Trump

title: mum cuddled five year old
story: NewsMum cuddled five-year-old daughter for the first time in months as dad drove her body to hospice to donate her brainClare Gregory donated her little girl Olivia’s brain for tumour research after she lost her le to a tumour so rare only 40 children a year are diagnosed with itShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByCarol Dyce17:49, 18 SEP 2018Updated22:33, 18 SEP 2018Newsthis.style.display='none'"/Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror/news/video/brain-tumour-story-chose-13269172,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-M3TH25P,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailLittle Olivia was dressed in her pyjamas and wrapped in a blanket - her mum Clare was cuddling her and stroking her soft blonde hair while dad Tony drove them through the empty streets in the early hours. But it wasn’t an everyday family scene as  they were heading home after a late party. Heartbreakingly Clare was cradling Olivia’s leless body just hours after she died at home, weeks before her sixth birthday – nearly a year after being diagnosed with a rare, aggressive brain tumour. Each second seemed on freeze frame as they drove Olivia to a hospice to give a most precious gt – their precious daughter's brain and spine for research into the tumour that killed her – a Dfuse Intrinsic Pontine Glioma .  “My heart was shattered Olivia was dead but I loved being able to cuddle her again,” said Clare Gregory from Wickford, Essex. “I hadn’t been able to do that for two months as she’d been so ill she didn't want anyone touching her. “I cradled her like a new-born baby as Tony drove with our other daughter, Eva, beside him.” At Little Havens Hospice, she gently carried Olivia into the bereavement room, with twinkling fairy lights and Disney songs softly playing in the background. “It was so peaceful and quiet,” said Clare.  “We tucked Olivia up in bed and she looked like she was just asleep – our little Sleeping Beauty.” Olivia was in a special chilled bed so they were able to spend some more time with her. Then she was taken to Great Ormond Street Hospital  in London for the brain donation to its INSTINCT programme, co-funded by The Brain Tumour Charity . Now Clare wants to “shatter the taboo” of talking about donating brains for research in the hope of one day saving other families their heartache. A video of her and another parent talking about their daughters’ brain donations will be shown at The Brain Tumour Charity’s Nurses and Allied Health Professional Conference tomorrow .  The video aims to encourage more health professionals to make patients and parents aware that brain donation is an option. The family’s nightmare started in early 2017 when Olivia became increasingly tired. “From being a normal, lively little girl all she wanted to do was lie down,” said Clare who works for an investment bank. “She’d come home from school and flake out on the settee and, at bed time, she was out like a light.” During the May half-term, the family went on holiday to Great Yarmouth. “Instead of running around, Olivia would say ‘Daddy, you’ll have to carry me’ “She’d also been waking up on and off with headaches and nausea. “And she was always falling over.” Clare took Olivia to the GP twice and was told it was a virus and adenoid problems. “But I just knew something was dreadfully wrong,” she said. On June 1 2017, Olivia woke up in the middle of the night vomiting. Clare took her to A &amp E at their local hospital where she was again told Olivia had a virus and sent home with Calpol and Diorlyte. Two days later, Olivia kept losing her balance and was lethargic. Clare took her to a private GP and got an appointment with a consultant paediatrician the next day. Back at home, Clare found found The Brain Tumour Charity’s HeadSmart campaign, online, which raises awareness about children’s symptoms.  Ticking off Olivia’s symptoms one by one, Clare felt sick. “I said to my mother-in-law, ‘I think the consultant is going to say Olivia has a brain tumour.’” she recalls. “But when I told the consultant about my fears, he just said, ‘oh no, brain tumours are very rare.’ “I asked him why should Olivia be exempt? Why shouldn’t she have a brain tumour?” Two days later, Olivia was worse and the weight was dropping off her. “I told Tony I was going to take to her to A &amp E in the morning and that I wouldn’t leave until they gave her a scan,” said Clare. “At hospital, a nurse said she believed me when I told her I thought Olivia had a brain tumour. “She trusted my instinct and that I knew my child.” Olivia had an MRI scan and they had to wait hours for the results. “We had the long walk to the relatives’ room where doctors told us they’d found a ‘mass’ on Olivia’s brain,” said Clare. “I just replied ‘I know’ as Tony sat in shock.” The next day, Olivia had emergency surgery to put a shunt in her brain as she had hydrocephalus – fluid on the brain.  Surgeons took a biopsy which revealed she had an inoperable DIPG, which only affects around 40 children a year with a prognosis of 9-12 months. “The strange thing was that I’d never been able to imagine Olivia growing up,” said Clare. “Whether that was mother’s instinct, a premonition or coping mechanism, I don’t know. “But I just couldn’t see her in my mind as an older child.” Clare instantly accepted Olivia was going to die. “I had no choice, but what I couldn’t bear was the thought of her suffering,” she said. But it still came as a shock when doctors said that Olivia had 9-12 months to live. “I heard this gasp and realised it was me,” said Clare. During the summer holidays, Olivia had six weeks of radiotherapy and also started The Brain Tumour Charity-funded Biomede trial , the UK’s first adaptive trial for children with high-grade  brain tumours. She had few side-effects but her steroids made her put on weight and suffer mood swings. Determined to make the most of every second, the family banked happy memories, including a trip to Lapland UK, holiday in Marrakech, a simulated Tube drive, swimming with the dolphins in Dubai and EuroDisney. “We just did our best to carry on – we had Eva to think about, too,” said Clare. “Despite everything, there was still plenty of laughter – Olivia had a wicked sense of humour and loved lip-synching to her favourite group Little Mix’s songs. “And she and Eva were so funny together.”  Four months after Olivia’s diagnosis, Clare met another mum through a Facebook DIPG support group, who told her how her adult daughter had donated her brain. “It was a light bulb moment,” said Clare. “Tony and I met up with her and her husband. There was none of that head-tilted sympathy – they got it. “I was already 99.9 per cent sure I wanted to donate Olivia’s brain but meeting them confirmed my decision. “Talking to them calmed Tony’s fears about what would happen and how she would look afterwards.” Clare saw it as a way for Olivia to “leave her footstep on the world.” “I knew Olivia would never grow up or have a job, so I decided donating her brain for research would be her job,” she said. Clare got in touch with her local brain bank. “It was straight forward – I filled in some forms and put them away,” said Clare. “You didn’t have to sign them until after your child died, so you could change your mind.” They talked about it in code at home as “the gt.” By February, Olivia was weaker down her right side and had slurred speech. “It was coming up to nine months after diagnosis - it always felt like the clock ticking,” said Clare. Olivia’s MRI scan on March 22 revealed her tumour was growing again. She was now in the final stages of her le. Over the next few months, Olivia spent more and more time sleeping. “Olivia wanted to be at home with us so we set up a hospital bed in our lounge,” said Clare. “For five weeks, she couldn’t speak or swallow. It was horric.” June 5 2018 is a date which will be etched in their hearts forever. “Olivia was on morphine and I will never forget the dreadful sound of her breathing,” said Clare.  “Tony or I were always at her side and she just wanted to hold our hands all the time.” Clare rang her palliative care doctor for advice about Olivia’s pain relief. “While I was on the phone, she was holding Tony’s hand and just turned her head towards me,” said Clare. “Suddenly the awful noise stopped – she’d stopped breathing. “I kept saying ‘oh my god, oh my god, it’s over, it’s over’ down the phone. “The relief she wasn’t suffering any more was unbelievable. “She looked so peaceful.” Before they woke Eva up, the couple had time with Olivia to say their goodbyes. “We wanted – needed - that time –a bit like that precious time alone after giving birth,” said Clare. “I told Olivia, ‘I’m so sorry Mummy couldn’t fix this and save you.’” Tony’s parents who live nearby came to see Olivia and they woke Eva to tell her Olivia had died. “We all took it in turns to kiss her and say our goodbyes,” said Clare. They drove her to hospital themselves instead of ringing an ambulance as they wanted to be alone with her and had a letter saying they were taking Olivia for brain donation. After they spent some time with Olivia at the hospice, she was taken to GOSH for the brain donation. She was then taken back to the hospice in a pink coffin her big sister had chosen until her funeral a week later. “There were no scars or signs Olivia had donated her brain, except for a small mark under her hairline,” said Clare.  “She looked perfect. “I just wanted the cancer out of her – so that she was pure for her funeral and her ashes are pure.” Now Clare is sharing her story to help The Brain Tumour Charity raise awareness about how vital brain donation is for research. “We don’t call it a donation – we call it a gt – as it’s the greatest gt a parent can give,” said Clare. “Gting Olivia’s brain is a huge comfort as she is still leaving her trace on the world. “No one once asked me or even mentioned it was a possibility and I totally understand it’s not for every family, but I hope sharing my story gives more health professionals the confidence to ask the question. “It’s too late for my daughter but donating her brain for research may help other children in the future. “It gives me a glimmer of hope.” Poignantly, one of the videos Clare treasures is from Christmas when Olivia and Eva, 11, used an angel filter. Smiling into the camera, adorned with halo and wings, Olivia says, “Look, I’m a  angel because I can fly!” “Watching it is so bitter sweet - now she really is our  angel looking over us all,” said Clare. “Not a day goes by that I don’t ache for Olivia but  we help to one day save just one family our heartache it’s worth it – and I think our little angel would be proud of us.”

title: aldi launches hangover free prosecco
story: NewsAldi launches 'hangover free' prosecco for just £7.99 - and we're very excitedThe supermarket has come up with a bottle of bubbly that has less hangover-causing sulphites in itShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByAmy Coles21:21, 18 SEP 2018Updated21:38, 18 SEP 2018NewsProsecco is lovely, but it can cause some very bad headaches "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThere's only one downside to enjoying a few crisp, cool glasses of prosecco and that's the inevitable hangover. Depending on how much you've drunk that could be in the form of a throbbing headache that keeps you bed bound all day. But what  you could enjoy prosecco to your heart's content, without the suffering the morning after? Aldi have come to the rescue with a 'hangover free' bottle of bubbly, part of its new line of organic wines. The &pound7.99 bottle of organic prosecco is sourced from the Corvezzo family's 150-hectare estate, 30km north-east of Venice. The winery is also eco-friendly and committed to using renewable energy. And that's not all. The fruit for the prosecco is grown with “no pesticides or herbicides” – another factor thought to lessen the chances of a hangover. Tweeting about its new organic range recently, the supermarket made a nod to the drink’s ‘hangover proof’ qualities, writing: We’re raising a glass this Organic September to our range of delicious, organic wine. Apparently, they’re hangover-proof… better have a glass to find out.

story: NewseBay seller accidentally posts photo of 'high dose ecstasy pills' on clothing listingThe seller from Wolverhampton had listed the dark blue 'retro adidas jacket' for auction - but included a picture of something else entirelyShare&nbspByDavid KeaneHana Carter16:58, 18 SEP 2018NewsThe seller posted a photo of a hand holding the bag of pills "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAn eBay seller posted a photo of a what appeared to be a bag full of ecstasy pills on a clothing listing by mistake. The UK seller had listed the dark blue 'retro adidas jacket' for auction with an opening bid of &pound19.99 last Friday. But along with two photos of the garment, was a photo of a hand holding dozens of more hexagonal-shaped pills. However the item's activity log shows the seller made an edit to the listing in the early hours of Saturday morning to remove a picture.  The pills, off-white in colour, feature a skull on one side and two back-to-back Ps on the other, which according to ectasydata.org are identical to 'Philipp Plein' stamped pills, listed as 'high dose'. Before the extra image was deleted, one eBay shopper had spotted the error and shared a screenshot of it on Facebook. eBay shopper Emily, who wished to withhold her surname, wrote: Rule &pound1. They also ended the listing for the jacket two days early after being approached. The unnamed seller said: It was a picture from a groupchat... I'm not comfortable with you putting it out there as can be taken and viewed in a terrible way when it's not what it looks like.

title: friend who supplied ecstasy tragic
story: NewsWoman admits supplying 'MDMA bomb' to friend who died during final university 'blow-out'Katherine Lavin, 21, admitted supplying a controlled class A drug and possession of cannabisShare&nbspByNathan Sandhu16:19, 18 SEP 2018Updated16:30, 18 SEP 2018NewsJoana Burns, 22, died after taking MDMA on a night out in Sheffield "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe college pal who supplied ecstasy to a tragic student who died during a final university 'blow-out' was warned she faced jail today. Katherine Lavin, 21, was given the warning after admitting supplying a controlled class A drug and possession of cannabis. An inquest had previously heard how Lavin bought &pound7 bags of pure ecstasy known as MDMA for a group of friends including Joana Burns for a night out on June 6, last year. Joana had created two home-made 'MDMA bombs' by splitting the &pound7 powder into two cigarette wrappers. But the Sheffield Hallam University Maths student became unwell at around 3.30am and started fitting after complaining she was too hot.  She later died in hospital. Lavin, 21, from Stockport, Greater Manchester, pleaded guilty to supplying a controlled drug of class A on June 6, 2017, and possession of cannabis at a previous hearing. Computer science student Benjamin Williams, 25, today also pleaded guilty to supplying a controlled drug of class A. Both were bailed and will appear at Sheffield Crown Court on October 12 for sentencing. Addressing both defendants, Recorder of Sheffield judge Jeremy Richardson QC said: This matter is now ready for sentence.  Unfortunately, it's impossible for you to be sentenced today but you will be sentenced on the date in October. Please, read nothing into the fact that pre sentence reports are required and please read nothing into the fact you are being given bail. These are serious matters. All sentencing options remain open, that includes being sent to prison. At an inquest into the death of Joana in May, assistant coroner Abigail Combes recorded a conclusion of misadventure. Joana had attended Sheffield University's Student Union event night called Club Tuesdays on June 6, 2017. She had created two home-made 'MDMA bombs' by splitting the &pound7 powder into two cigarette wrappers, Sheffield Coroner's Court heard. The Sheffield Hallam mathematics student was in a group of six who had all taken the same amount - knowing what to take 'following research on the internet'. The group, which included Joana's boyfriend Lewis Birch, had been planning the night out for weeks and had all bought a &pound7 bag each of MDMA - which amounted to a quarter of a gram.  The inquest hearing was told one member of the group, Lavin, had bought the 'brown-coloured substance' for everyone in preparation for the night out on June 6, 2017.

title: katie hopkins end inevitable just
story: NewsopinionKatie Hopkins' end was inevitable - she was just a story, not a journalistShe paid the price in the end, says Fleet Street FoxShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByFleet Street FoxColumnist14:40, 17 SEP 2018Updated00:30, 18 SEP 2018Newsopinion"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailI have long felt sorry for Katie Hopkins. She is a woman not only out of her depth, has not only floundered for more than a decade, but has no idea where she's gone wrong. It's hard to see her without thinking of a fly batting itself against a window until it expires, able to see the fresh air but unable to find it. If she reads this - which she might, because she defines herself only by what others think of her - she'll assume I'm a Left-wing liberal about to rail against her Right-wing freedom of speech. No, Katie. Someone who knows more than you is going to explain how the hatred has suffocated you. We both have epilepsy - mine very mild, hers very severe. The condition strikes in her sleep, led to her being expelled from Sandhurst, to break vertebrae and frequently dislocate her shoulders. She recently had brain surgery that ended the seizures but left her with a hole in her skull and needing to re-learn how to climb stairs. She blames the medication she has needed since young for the fact her oldest daughter is autistic and her youngest was born with a deformed hip that required many surgeries to correct. Those would be enough disability for most people to deal with. But Katie has an extra one - a mistaken belief that she's a journalist.  Let's not be precious about the Street of Shame. It is a trade, not a profession, and the only qualication necessary is a level of enthusiasm bordering on mental illness. But somewhere along the line most journalists get training. They get it from a practical degree, a vocational course, or at worst from paying attention to people who're doing it already. Katie became a journalist because first she became a media star, and she managed THAT with what she called being outspoken and everyone else called being a right cow. On The Apprentice in 2006 she hogged the camera by making amusingly-nasty remarks about maternity leave, fat people, and fellow contestants. She resigned at the end of the penultimate show citing childcare concerns, which others mocked because she had known what she was getting into. But it's perhaps worth noting both that her concerns were for two disabled daughters, and also that she was mocked mainly because she'd been so happy to mock others.  Katie sold her story for six-figure sums, had celebrity spats, and was pictured in flagrante in a field with someone else's husband. She got a regular column in her local paper the Exeter Express &amp Echo , but it ended after an online poll found 84% of the readers wanted her fired. It was a hint she did not take. She was invited onto TV as a guarantee of ratings. Three years ago Buzzfeed reported a former staffer at This Morning said she was always willing to cause controversy from the word go. Such programmes involve a chat with a producer in advance, and Katie would immediately come up with a firm line on something, and then wheeled on-air to spout it with little thought from either her or producers about where it would end. So in 2013 when she told Philip and Holly she wouldn't let her children play with someone called Tyler or Chardonnay or named after geography, it was pointed out one of her children was called India and the clip went viral.  Katie learned to make money by being rude and unapologetic, and the media learned to shore up their audience figures with a wingnut. Inevitably, she was offered a national newspaper column, a place in the Big Brother house, and more opprobrium as the hate multiplied. In 2015 she used her column to denounce migrants as cockroaches, and it quietly disappeared before she popped up at another website which racked up &pound150,000 damages plus costs for her groundless claim that a pair of Muslim brothers banned from travelling to Disneyland were linked to al Qaeda. She met holocaust deniers, tweeted about being with crew of a Save the Children ship she didn't board, and had repeated applications to join UKIP rejected. She made a habit out of getting it wrong. She moved on to LBC, left after calling for a final solution to Islamic terror, was questioned but not charged over alleged hate crimes, and more recently staged a picture with children at a school without their parents' or teachers' permission, a gross breach of journalistic ethics. She has her own website and, one hopes, has invested in some defamation legal insurance. Now she's been sued over a defamatory tweet, lost her home, and had to enter an agreement with her creditors. All of it is due to the simple fact that she attempted to be a journalist without any of the necessary skills.  If Katie had experience of working in the media before she became its favourite monster, she'd have known that what you don't say is just as important as what you do. By all means say you're snobby about the name Charmaine, but it might be an idea to know Shakespeare was happy to use it for one of his characters. If you make a habit of racking up legal bills for your employer, be careful with what you publish on social media. If you are caught lying, stop doing it. Steer clear of people with swastikas in their Twitter handles and  you don't know what defamation is, look it up. But more than anything else the lesson that Katie needed to learn was this: that becoming a hate figure is a viable but short media career. She chose a path that was an ever-decreasing spiral of bile, and it was only ever going to lead her into peril. I'm not sure she knows how she got there. She started out as entertainment, and ended up with the twin Pyrrhic victories of being praised by Donald Trump and winning an IPSO ruling against the Daily Mirror about the fact she was not detained for taking ketamine in South Africa, but for spreading racial hatred. Now she's broke and the only people still paying attention are creditors and knicker-snfing Nazis.  Katie was not a journalist but a controversialist - built and brought down by her ignorance of how journalism works. Her name is flung at others who make a much better fist of it, along with accusations they all want to be like her. Nothing could be further from the truth - journalists, above all things, want to be right. Katie was just a story, and it's a sad indictment of the media that it relied for attention on a sick woman spouting proto-fascist lies. But the principal blame is on Katie herself. She had enough clues, from as early as her first interview after leaving The Apprentice when Nick Hewer said her new brand had made you famous, but it's made you loathed. And where's it going to take you now? She never seems to have asked where it would lead. Even with training, she would never have made much of a journo. She has a thick skin and bloody-mindedness, but seems to lack empathy, accuracy, self-doubt or persuasiveness. She is a curiosity, but doesn't have any. The first rule of journalism is 'never become the story'. Not just because it's professionally embarrassing, but because all copy finishes the same way - with the word 'ends'. * Fleet Street Fox's new book, A Bluffer's Guide To Journalism, is published in March. Pre-order here.

story: NewsMan, 72, calmly buys £6 Wilko kne to stab victim in street moments after pair got into argumentRoy Lowe, 72, has been jailed for eight years for the attack in Nottingham town centreShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByEd ChattertonHannah Mitchell17:57, 18 SEP 2018Newsthis.style.display='none'"/Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror/news/video/pensioner-buys-kitchen-kne-wilko-13267831,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-M3TH25P,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA pensioner calmly bought a 4.5-inch kne in Wilko to stab a man he had just argued with in the stomach. Roy Lowe, 72, plunged the &pound6 blade into body of his 38-year-old victim in broad daylight after purchasing it moments earlier from the homeware store. The video, released by police following the sentencing, shows Lowe stabbing the man in the middle of a crowded street.  Minutes before the attack, Lowe verbally abused a 24-year-old woman outside the Dog and Partridge pub in Nottingham before becoming involved in an altercation with the victim when he stuck up for her, Nottinghamshire Live reports.   A heated exchange took place between the two men, which can be seen in the video, before Lowe walked off, bought the kne, and stabbed his victim in the abdomen. The victim ran inside the pub followed by Lowe who was still brandishing the blade as customers watched on in horror - although he did not attack him again. Detective Sergeant Andy Buxton, of Nottinghamshire Police, said: This was a calculated attack where Lowe has bought a kne with the sole intention of stabbing a man who he had an argument with.

title: meghan markle grenfell tower community
story: NewsMeghan Markle Grenfell Tower community cookbook: 3 recipes created by women affected by tragedyThe Duchess of Sussex also wrote an emotional three-page foreword for the book, TogetherShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsBySteve Myall20:03, 18 SEP 2018Updated20:05, 18 SEP 2018Newsthis.style.display='none'"/Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror/news/uk-news/video/meghan-markle-seen-cooking-new-13258748,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-M3TH25P,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMeghan Markle has lent her support to a new cookbook with women affected by the Grenfell Tower tragedy. The Duchess of Sussex cooked with women from the Hubb Community Kitchen, who were affected and collaborated with them to create the book, Together. Meghan grew close to the team at the kitchen in the Al Manaar Muslim Cultural Heritage Centre in west London. She also wrote an emotional three-page foreword for the book, recalling how she heard about the fire while working in Canada, and how she wanted to help. Here are three of the book's recipes..  Ingredients  1 potato, about 150g 3 tbsp vegetable oil, extra for brushing 1 tsp mustard seeds 1⁄4 tsp fenugreek seeds 1⁄2 tsp cumin seeds 1 onion, finely sliced 1⁄2 tsp ground turmeric 1⁄2 tsp ground cinnamon 120g white cabbage, finely sliced 1 large carrot, 120g, peeled and grated 100g mixed red and green peppers, cored, de-seeded and finely chopped 50g frozen peas 1⁄2 tsp granulated sugar 12 spring roll pastry wrappers, 25 x 25cm 1 egg, lightly beaten salt Method Boil the potato in salted water for 30 minutes until soft. Drain and leave to cool, then peel and dice. Heat the oil in a large frying pan on a medium heat. Add spice seeds and fry for 30 seconds, until fragrant. Add onion, salt and cook for 2 minutes. Add turmeric and cinnamon and stir for a few seconds until the onion is coated. Add the cabbage, carrot and peppers and cook over high heat for 4–5 minutes or until soft. Add the diced potato, peas, 1⁄2 teaspoon of salt and the sugar and stir for 2 minutes. Taste and adjust seasoning  needed. Transfer to a large plate and leave to cool. Cut each pastry square in half to make two rectangles. Keep the pastry covered with a clean, damp tea towel to stop it drying out.  Working with one strip of pastry at a time and with a long edge facing you, fold the bottom right-hand corner of the strip to meet the top edge, forming a triangle, then fold the top right-hand corner over to meet the top left-hand corner of the strip, forming a square. Brush the single layer of pastry  with beaten egg and fold over to form a triangular pouch. Open the pouch and fill with 3 tbsp of the samosa filling. Brush wrap with beaten egg and fold over to seal the pouch. Place on a tray and cover while making the rest of the samosas. Preheat the oven to 200&degC and put the samosas on a baking sheet lined with baking paper. Brush tops with a oil and beaten egg. Bake for 10 minutes, then turn them over, brush the other side with oil and egg and bake for another 10 minutes. Coconut chicken curry by Aysha Bora  Ingredients  1 large chicken, jointed into 8 pieces, excess skin trimmed away 1 large ripe tomato, roughly chopped 1 onion, quartered 15g fresh root ginger, peeled 4 garlic cloves, peeled 6 serrano chillies, stems removed and de-seeded  2 tsp ground cumin 1 tsp ground coriander 1 tsp ground turmeric 2 tbsp coconut oil 2 x 400ml tins coconut milk 3 eggs, hard-boiled, peeled &amp halved Juice of 1⁄2 lemon, salt and pepper 10g fresh coriander, chopped Rice, chapatis or flatbreads, to serve Method Score each piece of the chicken in two or three places, slicing about 1cm into the meat. Put the tomato, onion, ginger, garlic, chillies, cumin, coriander, turmeric and some salt and pepper into a food processor and blend to a rough paste. Rub one third of the paste over the chicken, into the cuts and under the skin reserve rest of the mixture. Refrigerate chicken for at least 1 hour, or up to 5 hours. Preheat grill to the highest setting, and line a large baking tin with foil. In a large pan, melt the coconut oil on a medium heat add the remaining paste and cook, stirring occasionally, for 20 minutes or until all of the moisture evaporates. Increase the heat slightly and cook for 3–5 minutes until the paste is thick and dark. Add coconut milk and simmer for 25–30 minutes until sauce is thick. Meanwhile, put the marinated chicken, skin side up, in the lined baking tin and grill for 15 minutes, until well coloured and charred, then turn the chicken over and grill for another 5 minutes to make sure it is cooked through. Stir the chicken and any juices into the curry pan, bring to a simmer, cover and cook for 5 minutes until the flavours have combined. Taste and adjust the seasoning  necessary. Add the boiled eggs and the lemon juice to taste. Sprinkle with the chopped coriander and serve with rice, chapatis or flatatbreads. Caramelised plum upside-down cake by Faiza Hayani Bellili  Ingredients  2tsp sunflower oil, for greasing 300g sugar 100g unsalted butter, very soft 1⁄2tsp vanilla extract 1⁄4tsp salt 8 plums, halved and stoned 40g dark brown soft sugar 2 eggs, beaten 25g corn flour 50g ground almonds 100g plain flour 1tsp baking powder Method Preheat the oven to 170&degC. Grease a 23cm round springform cake tin with the sunflower oil and place on a baking sheet. For the caramel, put 225g of the granulated sugar into a small, wide, heavy pan on a low heat. Without stirring, let the sugar dissolve. Once liquid, let it gently bubble for 15–20 minutes or until it is a deep golden colour. Add 10g of the butter, half the vanilla extract and the salt, gently swirling the pan to combine the butter as it melts. Once fully incorporated, immediately remove from the heat and pour the caramel into the cake tin. Place the plum halves on top, cut side down, nestled tightly together, and set aside. In a large mixing bowl, beat the remaining butter together with the remaining granulated and brown sugar until pale and creamy: this will take 2–3 minutes using a electric whisk  you don’t have one, use a wooden spoon.

title: need loo near you new
story: AdvertorialNeed a loo near you? New “Sat Lav” map shows toilets across the UK you can use from public lavs to cafesDomestos has answered public calls for more loos with a GPS to help you find a convenience at your convenienceShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByDave Masters00:00, 19 SEP 2018AdvertorialClick on the Great British Toilet Map image below to reveal all"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThere’s nothing worse than needing the loo only to find that every public lavatory is closed. But Domestos believes that a clean and safe toilet should be within everyone’s reach so it is helping to answer the public’s prayers. Its Use Our Loos campaign, launched earlier this month, is inviting businesses across Britain to sign up, open their cubicles and welcome everyone - customers and non-customers - to use their loos. And they’ve also agreed to feature on the Great British Public Toilet Map – a free interactive street map developed by Domestos and Public Convenience. The map - the UK’s largest database of publicly-accessible toilets - includes lavs that are located in local businesses as well as those at bus and train stations, shopping centres, libraries, leisure centres and hotels.  And it’s compiled using information from councils, the businesses themselves and YOU! As well as using the map to discover nearby loos, the public can help improve the service by adding new locations or flagging loos that have closed. Anyone can go on the website and add or edit the correct information about the toilet such as who can access it, opening hours, or facilities available. Just click on the Great British Toilet Map image below to reveal the map and find your nearest available toilet...   By visiting toiletmap.org.uk on a computer of smartphone, your device will automatically find your location and reveal your nearest available toilets. Users can also look for loos before leaving their home or office by typing in a postcode to search other areas.  As well as pinpointing the exact location of nearby public toilets, helpful information is featured about each one including whether there’s a charge and  it has an attendant. story: NewsRevealed: The most annoying things about work meetings and most overused office jargon - from 'no-brainer' to 'ASAP'A study found that workers across Europe spend an awful lot of time in meetingsShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByAstrid HallJon Livesey15:53, 18 SEP 2018NewsOffice workers spend a lot of time in meetings "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe average employee wastes nearly 13 working days every year - in ‘unproductive’ meetings, it has emerged. A European study of 2,000 employees in the UK, France and Germany found the typical staff member spends a total of 187 hours - or the equivalent of 23 days a year - in meetings. The bad news is 56 per cent of those get-togethers are generally 'unproductive' - and 66 per cent of those polled even admitted they make excuses in order to avoid meetings. The research by business travel hotel brand Crowne Plaza Hotel &amp Resorts also found one in 10 will pretend they got the time or date wrong, and one in 20 even admitted to calling in sick to get out of a meeting entirely. Mike Greenup, vice president brand management, said: “Meetings are essential for collaboration and reaching business goals, but ensuring catch-ups are effective isn’t always simple.  Experts also discovered most staff reckon 40 minutes is the ‘optimum’  for an effective meeting. Interestingly, the research found that German employees are the most likely to make excuses to duck out of meetings, with nearly three quarters confessing to doing so. By comparison, two-thirds of French employees and just more than half of UK professionals do the same. One reason employees excuse themselves from meetings may be due to the amount of catch-ups viewed as ineffective. More than one in three admit to switching off during meetings lasting too long, deeming more than half of get-togethers they attend as ‘unproductive’. Shockingly, nearly a quarter have witnessed someone else falling asleep, and a similar number have sent personal messages during a professional gathering . It also emerged employees are more likely to enjoy a meeting  it is held off-site and involves free food and drink. Over a third would get more enjoyment from a meeting with a relaxed atmosphere, and nearly two thirds would prefer for someone else to organise and run the meeting. Nearly two-thirds agreed mornings are generally better for meetings, with meetings between 9:30am and 11:30am revealed as the prime time for professional gatherings. The study showed that meeting pet peeves were also universal. Respondents said the most frustrating things about meetings, were people talking over each other, meeting rooms that are too hot or cold and people who arrive late.

story: NewsSingle mum with sepsis who lost hands, feet and part of her lung now preparing to climb Mount KilimanjaroCorinne Hutton, 48, became a quadruple amputee five years ago and was given a five per cent chance of surviving the potentially fatal infectionShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsBySarah Ward17:25, 18 SEP 2018Updated17:38, 18 SEP 2018NewsCorinne Hutton, quadruple amputee and founder of the charity Finding Your Feet "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA determined mother who had her hands and feet amputated following le-threatening sepsis is getting ready to scale the highest mountain in Africa. Corinne Hutton, 48, became a quadruple amputee five years ago and was given a five per cent chance of surviving the potentially fatal infection. She also had part of her lung removed last year - making her more at risk of altitude sickness. But despite her disabilities, single mum Corrine is preparing to climb Mount Kilimanjaro in Tanzania on October 1 to raise cash for the charity she founded. The ascent is expected to take five days, and she will be joined by ten other fundraisers.  Corrine said: Initially a lot of people tried to warn me against it, saying that the risks outweigh the rewards. I've taught my son to never say 'I can't' so it wouldn't be fair  I said it. If it's down to determination and the ability to keep going, I'll get to the top. I'm overwhelmed by the messages of support, donations and sponsorship I've received since announcing the challenge.  All of the money will change the lives of amputees for the better. Hopefully others will see my efforts and want to be the best they can be. The mother, from Lochwinnoch, Renfrewshire, has been building up her strength by working out with a personal trainer, doing Pilates and swimming. In 2015 she was the first female quadruple amputee to summit Ben Nevis and recently climbed to the summit of Ben Lomond. According to the NHS, early symptoms of sepsis may include:  a high temperature  or low body temperature chills and shivering a fast heartbeat fast breathing  In some cases, symptoms of more severe sepsis or septic shock  develop soon after. These can include:  feeling dizzy or faint a change in mental state – such as confusion or disorientation diarrhoea  nausea and vomiting slurred speech severe muscle pain severe breathlessness less urine production than normal – for example, not urinating for a day cold, clammy and pale or mottled skin loss of consciousness.

title: south sudan amnesty international report
story: NewsSouth Sudan Amnesty International report claims families have been burned alive and babies crushed to deathThe full scale of atrocities committed by soldiers and militia in South Sudan was today exposed in an investigation by Amnesty International.Share&nbsp&nbspCommentsByMirror01:20, 19 SEP 2018Updated01:31, 19 SEP 2018NewsTens of thousands of people have fled violence in Unity State, South Sudan for camps such as this UN outpost in Bentiu "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe full scale of atrocities committed by soldiers and militia in South Sudan was today exposed in an investigation by Amnesty International. Civilians described gang rapes on an industrial scale, toddlers being swung against tree trunks until they were dead and families barricaded in their homes to be burned alive. When a mother fled from one inferno carrying a small baby she was shot and the child crushed to death by a soldier, an eye-witness said. The testimony was gathered from 100 people who survived an offensive in Unity State, in the northern Greater Upper Nile region of the country, between April and July this year. Government troops are accused of giving free rein to youth militias, unleashing a wave of systematic slaughter. The epicentre of the violence was Mayendit and Leer counties, areas held by the opposition.  Witnesses described civilians being slaughtered in their villages. Some were burned alive in their tukuls - traditional mud huts which often have a thatched roof. A man believed to be over 90 had his throat slit. Nyaweke, a 20-year-old woman, said she saw soldiers shoot dead her father and kill a number of children in Thonyoor, in Leer There were seven men [soldiers] who collected the children and put them into a tukul and they set the tukul on fire. I could hear the screaming. They were four boys. One boy tried to come out and the soldiers closed the door on him. There were also five boys whom they hit against the tree, swinging them. They were two [or] three years old. They don’t want especially boys to live because they know they will grow up to become soldiers. In a separate incident in Rukway village, also in Leer, a couple and their two grandsons were burned alive in a house. Their daughter attempted to flee with her baby but she was shot and her child stamped to death. Even those who fled their villages had little chance of survival. Soldiers used amphibious vehicles to hunt those who had fled into swamps.  Nyalony, an elderly woman, told Amnesty she witnessed soldiers killing her husband and two other men: When the attack started, early in the morning while we were sleeping, my husband and I ran to the swamp together. Later in the morning, after the fighting was over, the soldiers came into the swamp looking for people, and sprayed the area where we were hiding with bullets. My husband was hit he cried out in pain. He was still alive, though, and the soldiers caught him, and then they shot him again and killed him. He was unarmed and wasn’t a fighter just a farmer.” Survivors faced unspeakable horror. Women and young girls said that they were abducted before being gang raped, sometimes for many weeks. Others were used as slaves to cook and clean for their captors. A 60-year-old man found his niece after she had been sexually assaulted by five men. She was just 13. My brother’s daughter was raped and she was going to die, he said. When they raped her, we came and found her and she was crying and bleeding … she couldn’t hide … she told me she was raped by five men. We could not carry her and she could not walk. There were also reports of sexual mutilation and castration.  Nyatap, who is around 32, gave a graphic account of her ordeal. Eight months pregnant, she was abducted with her five-year-old son and daughter, seven. There were 20 soldiers, she said. The other women who are not pregnant were raped. There was another lady... she was three months' pregnant and she miscarried. She was raped by 10 men. I saw it happen. They were just raping her under another tree. They put us in one compound.... there were other ladies... They would take turns raping them. Soldiers accused of carrying out the slaughter are also said to have looted and burned on a vast scale, making it virtually impossible for survivors who had fled to  to their homes. Amnesty claims that the situation was enabled by South Sudan's government failing to prosecute suspected war criminals for previous massacres in 2016. Four people had been identied but no action had been taken. Joan Nyanyuki, Amnesty International’s Regional Director for East Africa, said: “A key factor in this brutal offensive was the failure to bring to justice those responsible for previous waves of violence targeting civilians in the region. “Leer and Mayendit counties have been hard hit in the past, and yet the South Sudanese government continues to give suspected perpetrators free rein to commit fresh atrocities. The result has been catastrophic for civilians.” Amnesty has called for immediate end to all human rights abuses. Joanne Mariner, Amnesty International’s Senior Crisis Response Adviser, said: “It’s impossible to ignore the cruel reality –  the South Sudanese authorities had acted on our warnings back in 2016, this latest wave of violence against civilians in Leer and Mayendit might have been avoided. The only way to break this vicious cycle of violence is to end the impunity enjoyed by South Sudanese fighters on all sides. The government must ensure that civilians are protected and that those responsible for such heinous crimes are held to account.

The Mario character she appears to be referring to is called Toad, who looks like a cross between a man and a mushroom and has appeared in the popular Nintendo series since the late 1980s. Daniels claims she had an affair with Trump in 2006. This was around the time that the Apprentice star’s we Melania had given birth to their son Barron.  She added that she would dedicate the tell-all, which is due to hit shelves on October 2, to her young daughter. However she added that she would have to wait ‘until she is of a certain age’ before allowing her to read it. Daniels previously said on the ABC television show The View: You really didn’t think I would hold anything back? I’m gonna write everything and include it and people can think what they want about me but at least it’s the truth – it’s not like that they haven’t been thinking that about me anyway. The book is set to fill in details that were cut from her TV interview with the CBS show 60 Minutes which was recorded earlier this year. She said: Everybody knows that a lot of the 60 minutes  was cut down for time. There are things that I said in my interview that I really wanted people to know, that were very important to me, that I didn’t get to say.  Daniels has been working on the tell-all for about ten years, which will also discuss her career in strip clubs and the porn industry. While Trump has publicly denied the affair, his personal lawyer Michael Cohen pleaded guilty to campaign finance violations linked to hush money he paid Daniels through a front company.

title: woolly mammoths could return roam
story: NewsWoolly mammoths could  to roam in 'Ice Age Park' within 10 years thanks to cloning projectMammoths died out around 4,000 years ago, but scientists believe they can bring them back by cloning DNA material from remains of the giants found in permafrostShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsBySteve White16:48, 18 SEP 2018Updated16:52, 18 SEP 2018NewsScientists plan to use DNA material from remains of mammoths found in permafrost to clone the giants "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailScientists are hoping to clone woolly mammoths that will roam freely in a Siberian ice age park within 10 years. They will use DNA material from remains of the giants found in permafrost. And elephants could act as surrogate mums to carry the baby mammoths. The regional government in far eastern Yakutia has given experts the go-ahead to try to clone the beasts for the Jurassic Park-style reserve. Researchers are working with Russian, South Korean and &shyJapanese scientists.  Acting head of the &shyterritory Aisen Nikolaev said: “In my opinion, cloning a mammoth will happen in the next decade. “Technology is developing at an explosive pace, and what yesterday seemed to be scientic nonsense, today is an absolutely clear prospect for scientists.”  Mr Nikolaev first proposed an Ice Age Park with mammoths in 2014.

title: dundee house prices rise more than any other scottish city
story: House prices in Dundee are rising faster than in any other Scottish city, a new report has revealed. 100vw, 3000px" /Research from estate agent Aberdein Considine shows that the average home in the city was sold for more than £140,000 during the second quarter of 2018.This marks a 5.7% rise from the same period in 2017.Increases of 5.5% were recorded in Glasgow, Edinburgh, Perth and Stirling with Aberdeen showing a 1.2% drop.Dundee’s price inflation was recorded in April, May and June in the run-up to the completion of the V&ampA. Alan Cumming, national estate agency director at Aberdein Considine, said this was the first clear sign of the museum having an impact on the city’s property market.He said: “Dundee has been undergoing a renaissance as this magnicent new landmark takes shape on the banks of the Tay.“The city has a growing UK and global profile and with more than 500,000 people expected to visit over the next year, this is only going to grow.“Dundee is one of the most affordable cities in the UK for first-time buyers, which makes it a popular choice for young house-hunters.“We may well be at the beginning of a period of sustained price growth and I am incredibly optimistic about what the future holds for the city’s property market.”Across Scotland as a whole, prices have soared to a record high of £169,450 after a summer market heatwave inflated prices in 27 out of the country’s 32 local authority areas.But more than three-quarters of the people surveyed by Scotland’s Property Monitor indicated that they had no intention of buying a new home, up from 43% in the first quarter.Back in July, the Tele revealed how house prices in Dundee had increased by 1.5% in May, which contributed to a 5.4% rise over the last 12 months.During that time, the average property in the area sold for £121,580 – signicantly lower than the UK average of £226,351.Buyers who made their first step on to the property ladder in the City of Discovery in May spent an average of £104,591.In September last year, it was reported by Aberdein Considine that property prices in Dundee were rising twice as fast as the Scottish average.

title: dundee united gaffer csaba laszlo blasts referee after spot kick call
story: Dundee United manager Csaba Laszlo has hit out at referee Colin Steven after he gave a controversial penalty against his side on Saturday.Steven pointed to the spot on 11 minutes when debutant Rachid Bouhenna was adjudged to have fouled Morton defender Gregor Buchanan in the box from a corner.Michael Tidser stepped up to give the ’Ton the lead in a Championship game which finished 1-1 thanks to substitute Fraser Fyvie’s last-minute equaliser.Although Csaba was pleased with the fight they showed to win a point, he was frustrated at the referee’s performance.“I am really proud of the boys because it was a really dficult game,” he said.“You get a penalty against you, and I don’t want to talk about the performance of the referee because it’s not my job, but I thought it was a foul for us at first.“I didn’t hear the whistle, then the referee shows for the penalty but I think, to be honest,  he gives this penalty then he has the chance to give 10 others for both sides.“It’s just my opinion and it is not all about the penalty. I don’t want to criticise the referee but, according to me, it was a very soft penalty.“I asked my players  there was contact there but they didn’t think it was one which you have to give.”Of United’s display, Csaba added: “I think for 90 minutes plus added time we played one-way football.“The boys tried hard and it’s not easy when the clock is ticking down and you still can’t score.“In the first-half we had two very good chances where we should score and in the second half we were pressing Morton.“They were, more or less, 11 behind the ball playing very deep and they tried to counter attack.“Sometimes you have these games where you have to suffer but we have to be more clinical, must be more clinical.“We can talk about the many mistakes but we have to play faster, more with the ball into feet and up front but I think on Saturday everybody showed spirit.”

title: dundee united new boy booth says he shouldnt have tried to run off injury
story: Callum Booth admits had he been a Dundee United veteran instead of a rookie, two months into the season Arabs would have seen a lot more of him than they have.The 27-year-old is ready for today’s Championship clash with Morton at Tannadice and,  he completes the 90 minutes, it will be the first time since his debut in mid-July.That’s when he damaged ankle ligaments in the Betfred Cup defeat at Ross County, an injury suffered early on in the tie.It could have forced him off immediately but the fact he played on was, he admits, a mistake on his part that was caused by him being new to the team.“Firstly, it’s been good to be back, obviously being out for five weeks was a long time,” said the former Partick Thistle defender.“It felt like ages, especially when you join a new club because you just want to make good impressions and get games under your belt right away.“It was my ankle, I did in it in the first half at Ross County and quite stupidly played on.“The physio came on, had a look and I thought I could probably run it off. I did feel it for the rest of the game but being at a new club you just want to show up well in your first game.“If I’d been here a couple of years I would have come off but, because it was my first game, I stayed on and probably made it worse – I woke up the next day and it was agony.“The result was five weeks out and that wasn’t ideal but it’s in the past now and I’m raring to go.”What he isn’t doing is expecting to walk right back into the team and he knows, in the shape of fellow left-back Jamie Robson, he’s facing strong competition for that defensive berth.“Jamie has been doing really well, he’s a good player and it’s good to have competition. There are a few boys still out and they’re coming back, so there’s going to be even more and that can only be good for the squad.“I feel that, when we have everyone fit, we have a very strong squad and it’s just going to be a case of getting everyone fit and keeping it that way. There are always injuries, though, it’s part and parcel of football.”His mission now is to help however he can as United look to keep picking up points to mount a strong promotion challenge.The aim today is to pick up three points. He knows that will not be easy against a Morton side who will be something of an unknown quantity after their recent change of manager.It saw ex-United boss Ray McKinnon quit after just three months in chare to take over at Falkirk and former Rangers star Jonatan Johansson replace him.“Any team that gets a new manager, they usually take a couple of weeks to implement what the new man is trying to do. This is Johansson’s first game in charge so we are not really too sure how they’ll set up.“One thing we know is they have good inidual players and experience in there as well in the middle of the park.“It’s going to be a tough game and they are a good side. They’ve had a good couple of seasons where they’ve always been in or close to the play-offs and done well in a few cups.”For United the aim is to build on a three-game unbeaten run that’s seen seven points taken from the last nine, though Booth believes it should have been a full house.“We are going not too bad but,  we want to be winning the league, we have to be holding on to results like the one we should have had at Alloa last time out.“We didn’t play great but 1-0 going into the last 10 minutes, we should have seen the game out. Still, seven points from the last nine after a tricky start to the season is not too bad.”

story: New Falkirk manager Ray McKinnon has revealed the deadline day madness at the Championship strugglers – and even had a Dundee defender offered to him with just minutes to go till the window slammed shut.The former Dundee United boss was only in the door for a few hours after his shock switch from Greenock Morton.McKinnon managed to seal a deal for Rangers striker Zak Rudden on loan but narrowly missed out on former Tannadice loanee Anthony Ralston.He also revealed Dundee boss Neil McCann offered the services of former skipper Darren O’Dea as the clock ticked towards midnight.McKinnon said: “We had Darren O’Dea getting punted to us at 10.30 at night by Neil McCann. I was in the house!“We were trying to do a couple of things late at night. We were close, but we got Rudden, that was brilliant.“It was so late, we were trying to settle with players at 10 at night.
